body:
Something is up with the SILO import cronjob for our main instance. While it might be a simple hickup that could potentially be easily fixed by deleting the pod, I thought it'd be good to write down the observations as they could point at a bigger underlying issue.
The bottom one is the last-started pod, it's been "initializing" for 18 hours now, blocking start of cronjobs coming after. We should configure the cronjobs to fail after time X and not be "initializing" forever:

Logs:
container "config-processor-lapis-silo-database-config" in pod "lapis-silo-import-cronjob-mpox-28462895-k9x55" is waiting to start: trying and failing to pull image
----
container "silo-preprocessing" in pod "lapis-silo-import-cronjob-mpox-28462895-k9x55" is waiting to start: PodInitializing

https://argocd.k3s.pathoplexus.org/applications/argocd/pp-main-999?view=tree&resource=&node=batch%2FJob%2Fprev-main%2Flapis-silo-import-cronjob-mpox-28462895%2F1&tab=logs
My reasoning so far:
Cronjobs got stuck in “initialization” phase on an old commit sha, because the image build was stopped when I merged two PRs quickly in succession.
The cronjob should have been terminated when argocd synced to the new commit - but somehow this didn’t happen.
title: SILO import cronjob got stuck for 18h at "initializing" stage

At the moment the submission date is what's recorded when a sequences is uploaded, but then also updated if a sequence is revised.
Though this is how Genbank does this, I think this is quite unintuitive and would bet that most people don't actually realise Genbank works this way (I didn't).
It would be nice to have a way to make the two dates clearer. For example, to also provide/record a firstReleased date.

body:
Currently, Astro.url returns http://bla.loculus.org/bla rather than HTTPS. This is presumably because Astro is behind a reverse proxy and doesn't know it is SSL protected (although a header from Traefik should tell it that). We can probably fix this by setting base in Astro config (but we'd have to do that at build time).
But regardless, the issue is that this is sent as the redirect_uri to Keycloak, and so keycloak redirects, with tokens, go to http and not https. We can hack it to go to https by using replace("http://", "https://") in our JS that redirects to keycloak. BUT when we do that log in doesn't work and our logs say
"instance":"LoginMiddleware","level":"error","message":"Keycloak callback error: OPError: invalid_grant (Incorrect redirect_uri)","timestamp":"2024-02-23T20:50:25.409Z"}

I.e. keycloak doesn't like this https URI, it only wants http. It is unclear to me how to fix that.
title: Keycloak redirect URI should be https

body:
There's no real point in running unit tests/formatting when no relevant code is changing.
Github actions can be set to trigger only when a commit changes relevant files but that's probably not sufficient here - as we still want to indicate failure state on a future commit when the action failed in a previous commit.
Solution is probably to store test result in a simple key-value store where key is hash of relevant input files, and value is test outcome.
Then can simply look up if test has already been run on relevant input files.
This already works for Docker.
Main challenge here is to find which key-value store to use. One option is Github actions cache, which has downside of having limited size - but we seem to keep things around for at least a few days which should be enough here.
title: CI: Store CI results in cache and get result from cache if cache hit

body:
We should probably prevent that the last member of a group leave it - as otherwise the group and its sequences are orphaned and cannot be joined by anyone anymore, requiring admin intervention. As we want to minimize admin involvement, we should prohibit leaving a group when the person trying to leave is the last member left.
We could give a message saying "You're the last member and therefore can't leave the group"
Currently one can create a group, submit sequences and leave it, leaving no one behind without receiving any warning that the group would be orphaned, nor being blocked from doing so.
I'll put this as post-MVP as it isn't required to run the database.
title: Prohibiting leaving a group with 1 member to avoid orphaned groups

body:
As we invest into meaningful automated warnings generated in the preprocessing pipeline step, wouldn't it make sense to keep those warnings around for the public to see as well?
For example, if there's a warning about a collection date being suspicious due to it not matching with the known first occurrence of a clade, this would be good to see for those looking at the sequence - not just the submitter.
I'm not sure what we do with the warnings/errors data post-approve: do we throw them away or do they remain in the database somewhere? If they are still there, it might not be too difficult to tack them on to the sequence review page and make them show in tooltips/as markup somehow.
This is definitely post-MVP but it could be a quite nice feature!
What do others think? @chaoran-chen @theosanderson @emmahodcroft & co?
I.e. my idea is to somehow present the warnings also in this public view:

https://demo-prepro.loculus.org/mpox/seq/PP_000001Y.2
Essentially the warnings are contextual metadata on metadata.
title: Showing processing warnings in published sequences

body:
We currently have two levels for preprocessing annotations: error and warning. It might make sense to add a third one: info to indicate stuff that's not a problem but might still be of interest to the submitter.
Right now, the lowest severity level is a warning which might be to severe for things that are just informational. E.g. we may well have a button to "submit everything with neither warnings nor errors" which would mean we would annoy users by attaching warnings that are not a problem.
I really like the tooltips for the review page and it'd be neat if we could take full advantage here.
This is where this info would show up:
title: RFC: Add extra annotation level for preprocessing `info` in addition to existing `warning` and `error`

In NormalTextField, we set the type of an <input> (indirectly by setting the type of MUI's TextField) to MetadataFilter's type (source). MetadataFilter.type, however, can have values such as pango_lineage (source) which is not a valid type for <input>.
The generated HTML for a Pango lineage field looks as follows:
<input
  aria-invalid="false"
  autocomplete="off"
  id=":rr:"
  placeholder="Pango lineage"
  type="pango_lineage"
  class="MuiInputBase-input MuiOutlinedInput-input MuiInputBase-inputSizeSmall css-1o6z5ng"
  value=""
>

We shouldn't mix our application-specific types with HTML types.

At the moment playwrightSetup.ts creates a bunch of sequences for the tests to act on. But it does all this sequence set up in a global set up and then downstream a separate user is created for each browser tested. Then each browser tested does its own stuff. But in the current set up I believe it isn't easy for those browsers to each have a sequence in their own group for them to act on (e.g. to be able to click the revoke or revise buttons). Right now, we define an (output) metadata schema in Values.yaml that looks like this:
 - name: collection_date
          type: date
          required: true
        - name: clade
          type: string
          generateIndex: true
          autocomplete: true
        - name: outbreak
          type: string
          generateIndex: true
          autocomplete: true
        - name: lineage
          type: string
          generateIndex: true
          autocomplete: true
        - name: ncbi_release_date
          type: date
        - name: country
          type: string
          required: true
          generateIndex: true
          autocomplete: true
        - name: isolate_name
          type: string
        - name: author_affiliation
          type: string
          generateIndex: true
          autocomplete: true
        - name: authors
          type: string

Those who worked on the website seem to have decided to turn the machine readable (ugly) keys author_affiliation etc. into sometimes "Sentence case" and sometimes "Title Case" , i.e. Author affiliation/ Author Affiliation - as opposed to adding a separate display_name key to the config that allows us to explicitly code what we want to show in the frontend.
This is one of the causes of #1261.
I feel like we should either not prettify the machine readable keys or set explicit display values.
title: Add separate "display name" for each metadata column

body:
I've just tried the metadata download from the ebola-zaire instance on main. This is an example row. Few points for discussion:

 Why are aminoAcidInsertions (and nuc ones) included at all? We can include them but it's more related to alignments rather than metadata proper. After all we don't include snps, or deletions. Insertions allow the reconstruction of a sequence from alignments, but that's all.
 If aminoAcidInsertions and (nuc ones) null? It seems we use null for not provided, should we use that or rather use something like N/A? null seems to be simply the default in kotlin.
 submittedAt and released at is a unix timestamp, should we rather serialize it as human readable timestamp, something like 2023-01-05Z23:11:56?
title: Metadata in download: aminoAcidInsertions included, serialization to be discussed

body:
When downloading all Ebola data, I was surprised to find that zstd compressed download was very slow.
The bottleneck is clearly compression on the server, as uncompressed download happened in 2 seconds for me (60 MB raw), whereas zstd compressed download took 8 seconds (60 MB raw -> 340kB compressed).
That's a meager compression rate (of uncompressed input) of ~8MB/s.
Running zstd on the CLI on the same uncompresed file gets me a throughput of 2GiB/s and results in a higher compression ratio (327 KiB vs 340 KiB for the server compressed file).
Clearly the zstd compression on the server can benefit from some tuning.
Gzip is also slower than it need be, running at only 5MB/s, when on my CLI I get 230MiB/s.
Reproduce with e.g.:
# zstd
curl 'https://lapis-main.loculus.org/ebola-zaire/sample/unalignedNucleotideSequences?downloadAsFile=true&versionStatus=LATEST_VERSION&isRevocation=false&dataUseTerms=OPEN&compression=zstd&nucleotideMutations=&aminoAcidMutations=&nucleotideInsertions=&aminoAcidInsertions=

# gzip
curl 'https://lapis-main.loculus.org/ebola-zaire/sample/unalignedNucleotideSequences?downloadAsFile=true&versionStatus=LATEST_VERSION&isRevocation=false&dataUseTerms=OPEN&compression=gzip&nucleotideMutations=&aminoAcidMutations=&nucleotideInsertions=&aminoAcidInsertions=

# no server compression
curl 'https://lapis-main.loculus.org/ebola-zaire/sample/unalignedNucleotideSequences?downloadAsFile=true&versionStatus=LATEST_VERSION&isRevocation=false&dataUseTerms=OPEN&nucleotideMutations=&aminoAcidMutations=&nucleotideInsertions=&aminoAcidInsertions=
title: Download compression is too slow: <10 MB/s uncompressed, should be on order of 2 GB/s (200x faster)

body:
Currently, we configure the database in our docker compose file. The init script is inside the repository. This is not ideal since the deployment of pathoplexus would also need access to that script.
Instead I propose to use a database migration tool like https://flywaydb.org/ to provision the database from within the Kotlin code. Pros:

The database setup is bundled within the backend service. A deployment thus only needs an empty database and the service that connects to it.
As some point after the release, we will need to change the database schema, so we need a way to migrate between schemas. This will handle it out of the box: Starting a newser version of the backend service will migrate an already running database with an old schema.
title: Use database migration tool to provision the database

body:
Reviewing #1599 I got the feeling that we're not very explicit about which (types of) users are authorized to do what for various endpoints.
I've never worked on anything authorization related, so I really don't know the best practices, but I'm wondering if there's a way to make it more explicit for each endpoint what the authorization requirements are.
If we don't document it in code, it's easy that we mess something up when we refactor and we don't want to leak data to people who are not supposed to have it - it's more sensitive than other types of bugs.
Right now auditing is tricky. While I think that processing endpoints are only allowed to be called by a specific user, I don't see this documented in Swagger at all.
Discussion on Slack: https://loculus.slack.com/archives/C05G172HL6L/p1713273242036109
title: Document authorization more explicitly to make it easier to test correct behavior and avoid issues

body:
Instead of having all metadata in one long list we would like to allow users to group metadata into subsections with optional subheading, for example:
(no header)
Isolate name
INSDC id
Released at
Data user terms
Country
Authors
Sequence info:
Length
Nucleotide substitutions
Nucleotide deletions
Amino acid substitutions
Implementation details:
Metadata is defined in the values.yaml file, this is then further processed via loculus/kubernetes/loculus/templates/_common-metadata.tpl. When kubernetes is deployed (loculus/deploy.py) the metadata is converted into two jsons: the 'website_config.json' and the 'backend_config.json'. 'website_config.json' is read into the frontend in loculus/website/src/config.ts and the metadata is added to the schema. Prior to showing the metadata on the webpage (loculus/website/src/components/SequenceDetailsPage/DataTable.astro)  the metadata in the schema component is further processed into a tabledata: loculus/website/src/components/SequenceDetailsPage/getTableData.ts.
The schema (and the tabledata) is used at various other sections of the frontend and backend. So changes to the structure of the schema and metadata will not just affect the display of the metadata (i.e. schema.metadata is used for searching for specific sequences) but also other portions of the code.
title: Allow the metadata to be split into subsections with (optional) subheadings and further display options for individual subsections

body:
Suggestions from #1465:
Mutations: truncated lists that by default only span one line. Mutations could be rendered as little badge which makes them easier to parse than plain text C87665T. One line could be nucleotide mutations, then one line for each for each gene/CDS. This way uses can quickly find mutations in a particular gene (most of the time, people only care about a specific gene. Alternatively, the amino acid mutations could have a drop down in which you select the gene of interest (with a sensible default for each pathogen).
Insertions and deletions: can be handled similarly, though they are typically fewer.

body:
When I upload a big file (e.g., the 1.3 GB file that Cornelius provided here), I get a 413 Payload Too Large error. First I assumed that it was thrown by the backend but according to this config, the backend allows requests with up to 5 GB. At the same time, I get a CORS error for the same request.
My hypothesis is that something in front of the backend is aborting the request before the backend does it and returns the error. While it does, it does not set the right CORS headers as the backend would.
As part of the ticket, we should:

Identify whether anything is interrupting the request and fix it if that's the case.
Make sure that the CORS headers are properly set.
title: Payload too large error - unknown source and CORS error

body:
There's a chance that people could submit sequences to us that we accept, but that wouldn't be allowed by INSDC-databases. In that case, we should figure out how to handle this.
The specific use-case I know about is for HIV - if one has quite a fragmented sequence that has been aligned to a whole-genome reference, it will have a lot of gaps. Apparently if there are enough gaps, INSDC wants the fragments to be submitted as separate fragments, rather than as a whole-genome submission.
For that use-case, one possible solution is to break into fragments on our side and submit to ENA like that. However, we'd then need to remember to record and link to multiple INSDCs from our own record.
We should also be aware and log any other cases where we encounter instance where sequences we accept may be rejected by INSDC, so we can handle those, too.
(Not for Initial Phase)
title: How to handle 'INSDC unsubmittable' sequences

I have a gut feeling that this might be a bug in /get-original-metadata related to revocation entries: I for fun revoked something earlier, and this might make metadata null - something that might have been missed in the /get-original-metadata implementation.
That's quite an interesting interaction of endpoints, maybe we could add some revocation to the mix of E2E tests to detect things like that in the future.

body:
Both locally and on main, I am observing that for the dummy organism, there is a processing pipeline running with version 2 but for ebola and mpox, there is only a pipeline with version 1. That means that if we submit dummy data before processing any ebola or mpox data, the dummy data will be processed with a pipeline with version 2. Then, data submitted by the ebola and mpox version 1 pipelines will not be accepted anymore.
We should either disable dummy processing pipeline version 2 or run the ebola and mpox pipelines also with version 2.
title: Dummy organism runs pipeline version 2 but ebola and mpox run version 1

body:
At the moment, the backend maintains a single processing pipeline version and only accepts data that have the current version or a higher version. This is maintained across all organisms. I.e., if we want to upgrade the pipeline for one organism, we have to upgrade the pipelines for all other organisms as well.
This should be changed. We should be able to have pipelines with different version numbers for different organisms.
title: Make pipeline version scoped at organism level rather than global

body:
See: #1640 (comment)
We should add a boolean config variable to enable/disable duplicate ingest. For (almost) all test deployments, we'll want to have duplicate ingest to get data up quickly.
For production where a small race condition risk is not tolerable, we disable.
I looked into how one could lock across the cronjob and deployment but it's not so easy. There's no way to run a cronjob immediately after a deployment succeeds (i.e. earlier than schedule for first deployment), init containers also don't exist for cronjobs. Using a volume for this purpose seems overblown.
title: Allow removal of fast (duplicate) ingest for production environments

body:
When we have two ingest pipelines starting on a clean database, there's a very small chance of a race condition where both pipelines create an insdc_ingest_group
Rather than implementing locking which is unnecessary, could we just pre-populate the insdc_ingest_group as a service-group, similar to service account?
In production this will unlikely cause issues as the race condition is so unlikely (say 1 in 10000) and we will only create the group once in the entire app lifetime. But for preview deployments it would be nice, it would also simplify ingest code as we wouldn't have to create/query the group but could use a known id (passed through config say).
title: Possible group creation race condition: two ingest pipelines starting up

body:
The problem
Currently we do not handle the case when a user uploads sequences to NCBI and to loculus. We do not handle the case when the sequence is uploaded to NCBI first and then to loculus or when the sequence is uploaded to loculus and then the user still uploads to NCBI.
Current State of Ingest
Currently, ingest handles sequence uploads to NCBI as follows:

For cases where the sequence is uploaded first to NCBI: The ingest pipeline uses sequence metadata which includes the NCBI accession ID and other NCBI upload related information to identify sequences in NCBI and add them to loculus.
For cases where the sequence is uploaded to loculus first and then to NCBI by us: We plan to keep a list of loculus accession IDs with the corresponding NCBI accession ID - this should prevent us from reingesting sequences that we have uploaded. (Alternatively we could update our loculus metadata with NCBI upload information so that the sequence in NCBI will be recognized by our hash function as corresponding to our sequence).

Problem Scenarios


Assume now a user uploads to NCBI and then to loculus (which might happen when users test our service):
In theory if a user first uploads to NCBI and is able to properly add these metadata fields to loculus we will not reingest the sequence from NCBI, however if anything is not correct then the sequence will be flagged as different by us and we will try to reingest a new sequence. Both will be associated with the same NBCI accession ID... which might create problems. Additionally, even if the user is able to properly upload the sequence so that we will not reingest it from NCBI - it will not be in our accession ID list and we will try to reupload it to NCBI.


Assume now a user uploads to loculus and then NCBI (which might happen when users test our service):
Loculus will upload the sequence aswell - as this sequence will now have a different upload time and upload user NCBI will see this as a separate sample - this might have serious i
title: Discussion: How best to handle issues when the user uploads to NCBI and loculus

body:
The backend should validate the results of the preprocessing pipeline. When the preprocessing pipeline is implemented correctly, it should never fail but as the preprocessing pipeline can be implemented by external maintainers, we should be certain.
There was the question of whether to validate it in LAPIS/SILO or in the backend. For now, we will do it in the PP backend.
It should only validate the schema and we will start simple and check:

The expected fields are present.
There are no unexpected fields.
The data types are correct: string, int, float, complete isodates
title: Schema validation of the preprocessing results

body: Mpox is 200kb and one can easily imagine a (maybe artifactual) sequence that will e.g. give rise to the appearance of basically 200,000 deletions. Sending those to the client will be several megabytes and will likely have a negative effect on the browser. A simple solution would be to cap the number at a certain point and then send instead e.g. Too many mutations to display.
title: Avoid sending very large number of mutations to the client

To create another account and try to link my ORCID via that account. Nope, not allowed, ORCID already registered with other user:


It seems we associate the ORCID too quickly and there's no way back. This isn't great.
We have a few options:

Delete accounts that haven't confirmed their emails within a timeframe X (say a day)

body:
I've been investigating flaky E2E tests, improving the error messages to see more what's going on (see 0f1d4a2)
When I properly logged full backend errors, I noticed the following one (part of the "allow bulk deletion test"):
An unexpected error occurred while streaming, aborting the stream: java.sql.BatchUpdateException: Batch entry 0 INSERT INTO sequence_entries_preprocessed_data (accession, pipeline_version, processing_status, started_processing_at, "version") VALUES (('LOC_000Q6CP'), ('1'::int8), ('IN_PROCESSING'), ('2024-05-12 15:24:03.37018+00'::timestamp), ('2'::int8)) was aborted: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "sequence_entries_preprocessed_data_pkey"
      Detail: Key (accession, version, pipeline_version)=(LOC_000Q6CP, 2, 1) already exists.  Call getNextException to see other errors in the batch.

I'm not sure if this is just a test error, or this shows that our backend can end up in a bad state that we haven't noticed yet in manual testing. Would be good to investigate at some point. As far as I'm aware, the E2E tests don't have any special privileges with regards to the backend, so such a state could also be entered by real users.
To reproduce:

Fire up an E2E cluster
Run npx playwright test "pages/review/index.spec.ts" --repeat-each=10
Observe

It seems enough to just run lots of review tests in parallel to trigger this state. I know that the test will fail due to race conditions between tests (they just look at total counts and are not isolated from each other). However that doesn't mean that simultaneous uploading should produce an illegal backend state.
title: E2E tests put backend into state that errors with `ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "sequence_entries_preprocessed_data_pkey"``

body:
E2E test reveals a hydration error on the search page after clicking "search".
The errors are:
Text content does not match server-rendered HTML.

Hydration failed because the server rendered HTML didn't match the client. As a result this tree will be regenerated on the client. This can happen if a SSR-ed Client Component used:

- A server/client branch `if (typeof window !== 'undefined')`.
- Variable input such as `Date.now()` or `Math.random()` which changes each time it's called.
- Date formatting in a user's locale which doesn't match the server.
- External changing data without sending a snapshot of it along with the HTML.
- Invalid HTML tag nesting.

It can also happen if the client has a browser extension installed which messes with the HTML before React loaded.

https://react.dev/link/hydration-mismatch[missing argument]
title: React hydration error after clicking search button

However, this extends to not reprocessing data when the output is empty.
We should somehow save the hash in the output dir, so we can check whether the appropriate output is present or not.
it might be that we have some faulty logic when checking for cache: when preprocessing is killed, e.g. OOM, we might assume that the output data was produced, but it wasn't actually.

body:
Right now to see what happened to a preprocessing pipeline upgrade requires connecting to the database. That works for now while it's easy to access the database, but in production it will be laborious to go into the database.
So it would be nice to have an endpoint that summarizes the current status of preprocessing pipeline.
In fact, we could just have a dump of relevant database tables (read only) and without personally identifiable data - this would make debugging easy while still upholding privacy.
This endpoint would be restricted to the "superuser" (for instance) but not limited to debug builds, as this endpoint would be very useful in production as well.
Originally posted by @corneliusroemer in #1922 (comment)
title: Add database debug dump endpoint to backend

It's kind of annoying to have to submit both metadata and sequence files when revising something like a date - no sequence file is needed.
It's particularly a pain because if I only want to revise two sequences, I have to then go make a fasta file that only contains those two - that's a faff to just change some dates (for example).
Is there a reason we always require the FASTA currently?
(I can see how for sequence changes, we need the metadata so we know the PPXS accession)

body:
To me it's a little unintuitive that when revising sequences/metadata, there's no indication on the 'review' page of which values have been updated.
Just highlighting the fields that have changed (maybe in red or another colour) (or saying something about the sequence having been edited), would go a long way to reassuring users that the revision has gone as expected.
I don't know if this is easy or might be hard since it would require active comparison, but worth keeping in mind perhaps.

body:
When viewing the page for a revoked sequence, you can see a button to revoke it even more

You can hit the button, and it will go through the actions - you get taken to the review page where you can release the sequence.
it's then Revoked twice.
title: You can revoke a sequence that's already been revoked

body:
For me it's a bit confusing that when you view a revoked sequence, you get taken to a page that is much less obviously revoked as the latest version.
Ex, going to LOC_000Q447 (no version) takes me to this page (version 3):

Whereas going to LOC_000Q447.2 (with version) takes me here:

Which is much more clearly a revoked sequence, IMO.
In the drop-down version selectors this is also weird - they kind of seem to imply that the current version is not revoked:

I know the way we handle revocation somewhat constrains how we handle this, but I still feel we could probably improve on this a little bit!
Possible suggestions:

Add the 'revoked' background to the latest version, as well as the 'This entry has been revoked' banner to the top
Change the 'Latest version' or revoked sequences in the dropdown to red, not green
title: Show revoked sequences a little more clearly

body:
I may be missing a trick here, but once sequences are revoked, they no longer show up in your 'Released sequences' view as a user.
If you wanted to later then revise them, or even just see what sequences you'd revoked, I think you have to have noted down the accession somewhere and access them directly via URL (at least, that's all I can figure out at the moment).
This is probably pretty inconvenient, and we should allow some way to view your own revoked sequences easily, maybe via a toggle or something.
Before revocation (7 seqs):

After revoking the first seq (LOC_000Q3RZ.1) (6 seqs):

When clicking on sort by date in browse view, we currently sort dates ascending. This is usually not what users want in most cases. One is usually more interested in a) recently uploaded and b) recently collected sequences.
Sorting ascending by default makes sense for textual fields, but not for date. Maybe we could make default direction configurable for each browse field, or just hardcode it for dates to be ascending for now.

body:
Currently we have a metadata field called host_gender - for humans this is often considered 'more correct' since people (especially in casual clinical setting) will present/identify as their preferred gender, and this is what gets recorded (outside of specific circumstances).
For humans this is also probably a fine choice?
However, we also support non-human hosts - and here 'gender' doesn't make much sense. It would be silly to have two fields, probably? (Will people manage/bother to use them correctly?)
For animals in particular, sometimes knowing the sex may make a difference, if there's pathogen preference, for example. So that could be important?
Anyway, we should think about how to handle this appropriately.
title: Sex or gender?

(1) Desired input unclear.
At first, I did not understand what would be considered a query in the mutations search bar (should I be searching amino acid or nucleotide mutations?). With time, it has become clear to me that it is based on nucleotide number, and by including the mutating nucleotides (eg g327t) I could get to a mutation of interest.
(2) Results include partial sequences not spanning region of interest.
However, if I just type in 327 (to look at the loci of interest) I will also be given all of the partial sequences that do not have any nucleotide listed at that site (for WNV this means I see 995 partial sequences without the loci of interest and 1 with the g327t mutation).
(3) Can only search by nucleotides.
For my work with WNV, and much of the literature, we work primarily with the amino acid changes and not the nucleotides that caused them. Having a way to search by amino acids would be very useful instead of having to go back and find what nucleotides correspond to what amino acids (especially when amino acid switches could be made through multiple nucleotide changes).
title: Mutations search field is not intuitive

body:
For INSDC/ENA we want to have a pod (similar to the prepro pod) that will tackle the submission to ENA and handle issues, however we will need to have backend endpoints that give this pod the data that needs to be submitted and will also store the submission status and the new ENA accessions. This means adding 1-2 tables to the backend and and 2+ endpoints.
Note that in order to submit to ENA we require:

a unique project (this will be linked to the group metadata) - with its own accession value (actually ENA produces 2 accessions but they can be used interchangably)
a unique sample (this will be linked to the sequence metadata) - with its own accession value
and then finally we will need to submit the actual sequence data (an analysis in ENA with its own unique accession) using these two(+) accession values.

Ideally, we will create 2 tables in our postgres DB mapping:

each loculus group accession to its insdc_submission_status  and project/study accession value in insdc
each loculus sequence accession to its insdc_submission_status for the metadata, the sample accession and insdc_submission_status for the the sequence and the analysis accession value.

Probably we would like to have the status fields: PENDING, PROCESSING, COMPLETED and FAILED.
We might also want to store the number of attempts.
The Kotlin code

Send Values in Parallel (coroutines is an option for this) to the submit pod which will upload to ENA (most likely a python wrapper which will forward values to ENA) and use Concurrency Control: Use database transactions (Postgres should handle this) or row-level locking to ensure that no two processes or threads pick up the same item from the table at the same time:

val response = client.sendAsync(request, HttpResponse.BodyHandlers.ofString()).await()

Make sure processing is Idempotent: If the same request is sent multiple times, it should only be seen in ENA once - we will probably need to handle this in the submission wrapper (i.e. the submission pod)
title: Add insdc_submission status table to the backend

body:
Use nextclade instead of a regex search to determine which segment the sequence aligns with best to keep as much data as possible.
We are discarding around 2/3 of all CCHFV data in NCBI during ingest as the segment cannot be assigned. The big issue is the fact that not all records have the segment name in their description - instead a lot have the name of the gene that the sequence would correspond to. Additionally, there are multiple names for each gene/protein and abbreviations are not handled in a consistent way. Replacing the regex match with a nextclade alignment would resolve this problem.
title: Ingest: Improve segment assignment for segmented viruses from Genbank

body:
When I showed our kubernetes resource usage to Richard, he raised the good point that it is surprising that without any user interaction/load, we're using around 500 millicpus per instance.
I had previously looked into this: the main cpu load (when not preprocessing, which only happens right after startup) is backend and database.
My gut feeling for what keeps them at around 250 mCPU each is that for each organism (which are 5 by default right now), we:

a) preprocessing asks whether there are any new sequences every few seconds (to keep processing start delay low)
b) silo preprocessing downloads all sequences every 30 seconds

It would be simple to find out what the impact of each is by simply tuning the request frequency and plotting load against the frequency (this should give a straight line with the slope showing the average load per request per second).
I'm sure we could easily reduce the background usage significantly without sacrificing silo/preprocessing responsiveness. It's not a big priority right now but we should eventually tackle it.
Ideas

Silo load can be reduced by having SILO preprocessing submit a timestamp in the header saying when it last received data from the backend. The backend would keep track of the last time of modification of the "data_for_release" view, and can decide whether there's been new data. If no, it can reply with "no change" to SILO preprocessing. There's a bit of care required for making sure that every relevant change causes an update of the "last_change" timestamp in the backend, but this shouldn't be too hard. Simple logic (though with false positives): "whenever the database makes changes to a subset of the tables preprocessing and submission, it updates the last "release_data_timestamp" after the change transaction has completed.
There's nothing to preprocess if: since the last request to preprocess, there haven't been any changes to the preprocessing and submission tables. Looks like the same timestamp might be usable h
title: Improve efficiency of frequently polled backend endpoints

body:
There's a use case for loculus that purposefully excludes user submission/seqsets and only enables ingest.
Example: I want to enhance open data (Genbank) with any or all of
a) lineages/clades
b) group segments
c) custom fixes (date normalization/corrections/...)
In many ways, this is what we have as https://full-mpox.loculus.org or https://rsv-for-fun.loculus.org at the moment and it's already incredibly useful.
Why would one want to allow disabling submission/seqsets?

No need to worry about users misunderstanding the purpose of the instance and uploading real data just to find that it gets deleted (@chaoran-chen is championing this and argues for need for a very visible banner to show it's a debug instance which is a good point. Disabling submission outright would avoid any ambiguity)
Simplifies setup: No need to register/get secrets for ORCID/DOI etc.
No need to worry about user privacy/PII: no submission -> no registration -> no PII -> no worries
No need for persistent database if one purposefully decides not to attach any meaning to loculus accessions
Lowers barrier of entry for those who want to self-host/try out loculus: have simple "hello-world" like minimal setup that is still useful for analytics purposes
Submission/Seqsets are not necessary for pure analytics purposes, e.g. when making dashboards based on public data

Based on the current state of our software, I feel we're not yet at a state where things are easy enough to setup that non-core devs would want to host a full Loculus instance, however, we are totally at a state where we could offer "read-only" Loculus for essentially all viruses in NCBI virus (save for SARS-CoV-2 due to various parts of the toolset not yet being memory efficient enough - thought this is easily fixed).
I'm not suggesting at all to drop our goal of making full Loculus reusable - I'm just suggesting that this is not the only goal worth pursuing and that thinking about a more manageable minimal viable product for reuse might be
title: Allow disabling of submission/seqsets to allow pure analytics usage of loculus

body:
Occasionally, a race condition happens (unlikely in production but possible) when 2 ingests run in parallel and submit the sequences after having queried existing submissions before the other one submitted:
The sequence could be like:

A gets previous submissions: None
B gets previous submissions: None
A submits all, since all are new
B submits all, since it also thinks all are new

The reason is that a) getting previous submissions and b) submitting is not atomic/a single transaction, there's a delay (usually small, but can be big if a pipeline hangs/system overloaded etc.)
An easy way to fix this is to allow the pipeline to use a timestamp when it got the previous submissions, and submit that timestamp with the submission. The backend would then reject the submission if there has been a more recent submission, after the original timestamp.
All this would require is:

for the backend to set a timestamp "timestamp_of_start_most_recent_submission", and update it whenever the submit endpoint is hit
the backend would return this timestamp whenever ingest asks for previous submissions
ingest would submit that returned timestamp to the backend together with submissions
the backend would reject the submission if the timestamp values are not identical

Right now, ingest assumes that this race condition never happens, so it ends up crashing once the race condition has happened. While we could try to work around it in ingest, the cleanest way is for the backend to implement the above transaction logic. Ingest can't undo submissions, so the best is for backend to offer transactions like this.
While it might seem that this feature is only useful to the special submitter "ingest", as ingest uses the normal public API for submission, this feature would help anyone who programatically submits to Loculus and wants to ensure they don't publish duplicates.
I label this a bug and an enhancement, because there is no way that a submitter can avoid this race condition with the current A
title: Add transactional submission logic to backend: Avoid submission race condition causing duplicates

body:
We currently treat per-segment metadata like any other metadata on seqDetails page (and elsewhere on the website).
We are thus throwing away intrinsic structure and making the seqDetails page overwhelming (CCHF has 3 segments, for flu with 8 it'd be even more overwhelming).
We can group in two ways: top level being field name or top level being segment. I think I'd prefer top level being segment. Reason is that if you look at for example per segment QC metadata, you study one particular segment and look at multiple fields rather than looking at a metadata field across segments.
Increase in per-segment metadata fields comes with: #2108
Example of current state (once #2108 is merged):
title: Improve how seqDetails page displays per-segment metadata

body:
Currently there is a hard constraint on all grouped segmented pathogens that the ncbi_release_date and the ncbi_update_date must be the same for all segments.
To allow different dates we need to:

Fix prepro: Either allow date concatenation e.g. segment1:date1/segment2:date2... or take max/min date - for update date this is a quick fix.
Fix ingest/reingest: This is primarily important for ncbi_release_date. Reingest checks the hash of each segment group by recalculating the submissionId of that group, which is comprised of the concatenated INSDC Ids of the grouped segments. If a new segment is added to the group the new submissionId will contain another INSDC Id and thus will not be found by reingest. This means that we will keep the old segment group and create a new segment group containing one more segment. The old segments will have two accessions in loculus. This should be easy to fix with a change to the compare_hashes.py script - as we get a list of all INSDC submissionIds associated with a sample when we query loculus.
title: Segmented pathogens: Allow different INSDC-submission related dates in ingested data

body:
We need to make sure that any future changes to the hash function used in ingest/reingest will be backward compatible once the database is persistent.
See: #2171 for an example of a potential future change.
To make sure the hash function does not change we should add a test to the ingest function and also potentially already now change how ingest handles multi-segmented organisms - instead of having one hash per organism potentially we should have one per segment as this is what we receive from INSDC.
Reingest checks the hash of each segment group by recalculating the submissionId of that group, which is comprised of the concatenated INSDC Ids of the grouped segments. If a new segment is added to the group the new submissionId will contain another INSDC Id and thus will not be found by reingest. This means that we will keep the old segment group and create a new segment group containing one more segment. The old segments will have two accessions in loculus. This should be easy to fix with a change to the compare_hashes.py script - as we get a list of all INSDC submissionIds associated with a sample when we query loculus.
title: ingest: Add tests for the hash function: avoid version increase when no change, avoid grouping changes leading to multiple sequences being uploaded

body:
MVP tasks:

 : Create a backend endpoint
 : Get a clear overview of all the upload commands
 : Do one test with the broker account on production prior to real thing - we can get ENA to delete 1 test submission

Submission steps:

 0. : Create a pod with permissions to call loculus for submission data, group data and post external (ena - related) submission results (e.g. insdc_accession). It should have a main submission table to store submission status, as well as project + sample + assembly submission table for each individual stage.
 a. should have ena submission privileges.
 b. add flyway to ena pod and have tables initialized by flyway to track versions
 1. : Get a list of sequences that are approved for release and should be submitted to ENA (i.e. have not started submission process=not in submission table and are not from INSDC).
 a. Send slack notification
 #2403
a. Add sequences to main submission table. This should trigger the submission process
 #2397
a. Get group info from loculus
b. check if project exists for (group, organism) already
c. if not add details to table: create xml with project details, start submission, keep progress in table, then add results in table.
d. Make sure when project submission finished project_submission is marked as complete in main submission table.
 #2398
a. When project submission is finished, add accession to sample table with status ready for sample submission
b. Create submission xml
c. start submission, keep status of submission in table, then add results to table when finished.
d. Make sure when sample submission finished sample_submission is marked as complete in main submission table.
 #2399
a. When sample submission is finished, add accession to analysis table with status ready for assembly submission
b. create submission xml
c. start submission, keep status of submission in table, then add results to table when finished.
d. Make sure when assembly submission finished assembly_submission is marked as complete in mai

body:
As discussed in the call - it would be cool to have 3 python functions for ENA submissions.

project
sample
assembly

Functions should handle curl post errors correctly and should let users add optional metadata fields, probably sth like TITLE=''.
For example project submission expects an xml file:
<PROJECT_SET>
    <PROJECT alias="{group_accession}:{organism}:{unique_id}">
        <NAME>{ncbi_virus_name}</NAME>
        <TITLE>{ncbi_virus_name} Genome sequencing</TITLE>
        <DESCRIPTION>Automated upload of {ncbi_virus_name} sequences submitted by {Institution} from {db}.</DESCRIPTION>
        <SUBMISSION_PROJECT>
            <SEQUENCING_PROJECT/>
            <ORGANISM>
            <TAXON_ID>{taxon_id}</TAXON_ID>
            <SCIENTIFIC_NAME>{ncbi_virus_name}</SCIENTIFIC_NAME>
            </ORGANISM>
        </SUBMISSION_PROJECT>
        <PROJECT_LINKS>
            <PROJECT_LINK>
                <XREF_LINK>
                <DB>{db}</DB>
                <ID>{group_accession}</ID>
                </XREF_LINK>
            </PROJECT_LINK>
        </PROJECT_LINKS>
    </PROJECT>
    </PROJECT_SET>

The submit_project should probably look sth like:
submit_project(username, password, url, project='', name='', title='', description='', taxon_id='', scientific_name='', db='', id='')

alternatively it could also just take the same params as the curl request - this might be easier for the start:
submit_project(username, password, url, submission_xml, project_xml)
title: Create python wrappers for ENA submission requests

           throw error; 
        
    
  

 throws an error when there is a connection refused to the keycloak server. This leads to an error, I think throughout the website, when this happens to keycloak connections. Potentially we could instead log an error without throwing to allow the website to still be accessed in read only. (I think we do do that in some contexts).
title: Should we stop throwing for keycloak CONNREFUSED ?

body:
Currently if a sequence originates from INSDC, the submitter and submitting group show up as insdc_ingest_user and insdc_ingest_group, respectively. While we all know what this means, it's a bit opaque to users, I realised when writing up the FAQs.
For example, when writing how users could identify if a sequence came from INSDC or was directly uploaded, one currently writes see if the 'Submitter' is insdc_ingest_user` - but this may feel like a random-code-word they have to remember.
One option might be to just change these fields to be a little more readable 'as is': automatic_insdc_sequence or something (though this perhaps still isn't super obvoius).
Another would be to add some customDisplay fields so that these show up as something more 'human readable' in the sequence view (and possibly in downloads). For example: Sequence from INSDC in both fields (since submitter and group don't really make sense here anyway).
title: Prettify `insdc_ingest_user` and `insdc_ingest_group` fields for user comprehension

body:
Here are my thoughts:
Definitions

Sequence ID: a sequence-specific identifier that Pathoplexus assigns
Revision: the version number of a sequence+metadata
Unpreprocessed data: the data that the submitter provides
Preprocessed data: the data that the preprocessing pipeline provides/derives based on the unpreprocesed data

There are three "regular" top-level submitter operations: submit, revise, and revoke:
When a user submits data, they send unpreprocessed data. For each sequence, Pathoplexus creates a new row in the "sequences" table. It generates a new sequence ID. The revision number of the sequences is 1.
When a user revises data, they send sequence IDs and unpreprocessed data. For each revised sequence, Pathoplexus creates a new row in the "sequences" table. It does not change any existing rows and does not create new sequence IDs. The new rows have an incremented revision number. A sequence can only be revised if it has the SILO_READY status (see below).
When a user revokes data, they send sequence IDs. For each revoked sequence, Pathoplexus creates a new row in the "sequences" table. The unpreprocessed data are empty. The "revoked" flag is set to true. The new rows have an incremented revision number. A sequence can only be revoked if it has the SILO_READY status (see below).
Example:
Given the following events:

Submit [{data: d1}, {data: d2}] -> ids: 1, 2
Revise [{id: 1, data: d3}]
Revoke [{id: 1}]

The "sequences" table would look as follows:



Sequence ID
Revision
Revoked
Unpreprocessed data




1
1
false
d1


2
1
false
d2


1
2
false
d3


1
3
true




The preprocessing pipeline runs for every entry where unpreprocessed data is not empty and adds preprocessed data, warnings, and errors.



Sequence ID
Revision
Revoked
Unpreprocessed data
Preprocessed data
Warnings
Errors

1

d1

true

...

When we update our preprocessing pipeline (e.g., when new UShER or Nextclade
title: Submissions and revisions and different stages

body:
We had some useful recent discussions about the complexities of multi-sequence ingest. At the moment, my understanding is that if someone updates a particular segment, that segment will have a new release date and that will trigger it to go under a new loculus accession. That specific aspect will hopefully be fixable by #2171 .
But IMO there's a broader thing we should aim towards which is just that all versions of a particular segment should ideally always be under the same Loculus accession grouping. There may potentially be edge cases where this isn't possible but I still think it's a good thing to keep in mind and to monitor.
title: Multi-segment ingest: different versions of a specific NCBI sequence should never(ish) end up under distinct Loculus accessions

body:
If a metadata field is in usually_identical_fields (see ingest/scripts/group_segments.py) and the contents of that field are different for different segments, ingest concatenates that input with an "\n".
Due to the constraints in the backend (i.e. type checking) we can only put fields in usually_identical_fields if they are of type string or we can switch to type string without any problems. Otherwise we need to make a hard decision if sth should be per segment or shared.
For example we currently cannot add ncbi_release_date and the ncbi_update_date into this category as they are not of type string.
title: Ingest/ Grouping: How to handle fields that are usually identical but can sometimes vary?

body:
When we submit to ENA they suggest we use metadata fields that they recognize (this isn't necessary we can just submit with arbitrary fields - but will make life easier for the greater community). The standard metadata template for virus data is https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/browser/view/ERC000033. I reviewed the entries they propose and would suggest this mapping of the metadata fields we offer on loculus to ENAs metadata fields.
Proposed Mapping from ENA fields to loculus fields:
"subject exposure":
  - exposure_event
"type exposure":
  function:
    name: concatenate
    loculus_fields:
      - exposure_setting
      - exposure_details
"hospitalisation":
  loculus_fields:
    - environmental_site
  function:
    name: match
    args: Hospital
  type:
    bool
"illness symptoms":
  - signs_and_symptoms	
"collection date":
  - sample_collection_date
"geographic location (country and/or sea)":
  - geo_loc_country
  type:
    - options: country
"geographic location (region and locality)":
  function:
    name: concatenate
    loculus_fields:
      - geo_loc_admin_1
      - geo_loc_admin_2
"host disease outcome":
  - host_health_outcome
  type: 
  - options: [dead, recovered, recovered with sequelae]
"host common name":
  - host_name_common
"host age":
  - host_age
"host health state":
  - host_health_state
  type: 
  - options: [diseased, healthy, not applicable, not collected, not provided, restricted access, ...]
"host sex":
  - host_gender
  type: 
  - options: [female, hermaphrodite, male, neuter, not applicable, not provided, other, ....]
lab_host:
  - is_lab_host
"host scientific name":
  - host_name_scientific
"collector name":
  - author
"collecting institution":
  function:
    name: concatenate
    loculus_fields:
      - sequenced_by_organization
      - author_affiliations
"receipt date":
  - sample_received_date
isolate:
  - specimen_collector_sample_id
"isolation source host-associated":
  function:
    name: concatenate
    loculus_fields:
      - anatomic

body:
I downloaded some metadata and noticed that the download file name was rather undescriptive: details.tsv. It's so generic that it causes duplication issues, e.g. in my case I already have 17 details.tsvs, so it ended up as details (18).tsv
One approach I find useful in practice is to use timestamped URLs. Anything is better than the current situation, though.
Off the top of my head, this might work well:
DOMAIN_ORGANISM_DATATYPE_DATETIME.EXTENSION

Where DOMAIN could be something like loculus, or pathoplexus, maybe this could be configured in values.yaml.
ORGANISM is obvious.
Filetype is good to have, e.g. metadata or sequences or aligned. Datetime could include minutes, or even seconds, to completely avoid duplicates.
Extra things we could possibly embed in file name:

number of records included
open only, vs. restricted included
...

I don't think we need to be very stable here, people shouldn't rely on exact filenames - this is more for convenience. We could possibly allow users to set filenames themselves if they are picky, maybe LAPIS supports that already?
title: Better file names to avoid `details (18).tsv`, e.g. `loculus_cchf_metadata_202407231323.tsv`

body:
In order to submit sequences (or assemblies in our case - see https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/submit/assembly/genome.html#manifest-files) we need to add the following three mandatory fields:

ASSEMBLY_TYPE: ‘clone or isolate’ - mandatory
PROGRAM: The assembly program - mandatory
PLATFORM: The sequencing platform, or comma-separated list of platforms - mandatory

These kind of map to our fields sequencing_instrument(=platform), sequencing_protocol/sequencing_assay_type(=program?) but not fully... I am also just assuming we would not get clone data uploaded - but maybe we need to add this as a field?
My suggestion would be to make sequencing_instrument and sequencing_protocol mandatory and just set ASSEMBLY_TYPE=isolate for all our submissions.
title: feat(ena-submission): How to handle mandatory assembly/ sequencing metadata fields

Description
When using the browse filter, it's possible to set clade=null, which breaks the search functionality. This results in no search results and the null filter not being displayed, making it impossible to remove except by resetting all filters.
Steps to reproduce

Open the browse page, e.g. https://main.loculus.org/ebola-sudan/search?
Type something in the clade field
Delete the entered text completely

Expected behavior
The clade filter should be removed or ignored when empty, not set to null.
Actual behavior
The clade filter is set to null
Additional notes - This issue affects all autocomplete fields -
Suggested fixes:
a) Never use null as a filter value ~ we do want to allow null if null is an actual value that occurs!
title: Browse filter sets field to null if text deleted

body: As @rneher found, the preprocessing gets stuck if the user submits a sequence that contains an invalid symbol (e.g., ?). This is because the Nextclade preprocessing pipeline is submitting the original sequence in the unalignedNucleotideSequences field back to the backend. Instead, "it should either reject these sequences, or replace all non-IUPAC characters with N." (quoting @rneher)
title: Nextclade pipeline should not send wrong unaligned nucleotide sequences

body:
As seen with #2562 if the prepro pipeline doesn't clean up a sequence or metadata as expected and sends this to the backend the backend will reject the submission but the prepro pipeline will retry sending in a loop. This means that users see sequences are stuck in a state of preprocessing.
Ideally the prepro pipeline should always submit data in the way expected by the backend but we should have another way to stop the prepro loop if after 5minutes or so the prepro pipeline has not succeeded in uploading preprocessed data to the backend. Then we could let users know they need to contact us to find out what happened and what is wrong with their uploaded data.
title: Stop prepro from getting into an infinite loop

body:
Ideally, when curating sequences from INSDC, we would like 1 curator to set up the revision, and another (different) to approve it and 'submit' it to become live.
However, at the moment, all sequences in 'Review' are auto-approved for INSDC-ingest-group. So, one reviewer sets this up, and it's auto-approved without having a chance for another reviewer to approve.
One possible fix would be to only auto-approve 'version 1' (.1) sequences, and anything higher than this (e.g. a revision) needs to be approved by a curator.
This would be fairly high-priority post-launch as we have our 'four eyes' principle written into our docs (and it's probably a good idea)
(As a follow up - re-edit docs after fixing this issue

Curator SOP
Data submission & processing)
title: Revisions from Curators to INSDC-Ingest-Group Are Auto-approved

body:
First of all, amazing work! I've been hoping for something like this for quite some time!
It seems like users upload consensus sequences, which is standard at the moment, but is there any interest in adding support for client-side consensus sequence calling from raw or mapped reads using ViralWasm-Consensus?

Web App: https://niema-lab.github.io/ViralWasm-Consensus/
Source Code: https://github.com/niema-lab/ViralWasm-Consensus/
Paper: https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/40/1/btae018/7515252

ViralWasm-Consensus uses biowasm to run WebAssembly-compiled versions of tools like fastp, Minimap2, and ViralConsensus client-side in the user's web browser without any need for manual installation of any tools
I can imagine having an upload interface where, if the user picks a FASTQ file, it automatically gets mapped to the viral reference genome and gets a consensus sequence called directly within their own browser, without any manual action on their part
The rationale for such functionality is to prevent/minimize bioinformatics errors from users (e.g. those seen in the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic)
title: Client-side consensus calling using ViralWasm-Consensus?

body:
It turns out some sequences in NCBI are reverse complemented with respect to the canonical orientation. For CCHF it's around 1% of sequences.
We currently don't accept sequences that don't align with Nextclade. And we do not --retry-reverse-complement, see code. We will definitely want to fix that - the question is whether we should reverse complement the unaligned nucleotide sequences or not.
For background see discussion: https://loculus.slack.com/archives/C05F8GKR06R/p1724871271644439
This doesn't just affect prepro but also ingest. For ingest PR see #2651
title: Handling reverse complemented sequences

@anna-parker brought up that she has repeatedly wasted time debugging deployment issues when the root issue ended up being insufficient CPU/RAM on the dev cluster.
While it is not tricky to check if this is the case, it's enough manual work and hard to remember that it's a hassle.
The solution to insufficient resources in the short/medium term is to take down preview deployments. That's easy to do, but one needs to know that lack of resources is the actual problem.
Solution: Somehow send notifications to a cluster-health Slack channel to inform us of resource shortage.
Possible implementations:

Hand-crafted, quick to set up: (Cron)job that streams relevant cluster event log entries to Slack
Possibly nicer in long run but requires more time to set up: Setting up prometheus (or something similar) rather than hand-roll
title: Dev cluster monitoring: send notifications to Slack if insufficient CPU/RAM or other cluster health issues

body:
This only affects preview instances (instances with non-persistent db)
If you see errors like this in backend logs or in preprocessing logs:
Caused by: org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: relation "current_processing_pipeline" does not

then likely a race condition has happened in preview deployments.
Specifically, when argo makes a revision update, if the backend is up and runs flyway on the old db, rather than on the new one, then the new one never gets the tables created.
Workaround for now: restart backend. But would be nice to fix eventually.
title: Preview race condition possible when backend up faster than new db, then it runs flyway on old db and new db isn't initialized

body:
Our current deployment appears to be bistable: once CPU requirements go above a certain level which is surprisingly low, maybe 30-40%, the cluster enters a locked state where CPU usage goes to 100% and doesn't easily recover.
The reason, I think, involves argocd restarting failed containers (things like prepro/ingest fail when keycloak is down, we probably should not fail but log/error/notify - so as not to make the situation worse). Restarted containers require more CPU than running ones.
We should investigate what the major contributors to the runaway are. Possible mitigations:

simply make sure we don't exceed 30% CPU usage, limit preview deployments
notify if this locked state is detected (e.g. if CPU usage goes >80%), or if there are scheduling errors in events
add extra nodes
give production proper cpu request budgets so production is not affected by cpu starvation overall
title: Prevent runaway CPU requirements in kubernetes deployments

I have a hunch that we don't use zstd dictionaries for compression of sequences. Using dictionaries will likely enhance compression efficiency by an order of magnitude which is essential for scalability and general resource efficiency.
One can start off using simply the refseq as the dictionary, though it'd be better to use a diverse subset of sequences for the best compression ratios.
If using more custom dictionaries, one would want to store the dictionaries used in a separate table. For now using the ref seqs seems like the best tradeoff for simplicity and efficiency.
title: Compress compressed sequences in backend with zstd dictionary

body:
Right now we only have 2 files in the backend migrations folder, but they will become more numerous.
For reading the code, it doesn't matter really what all the migration files are, what one cares about is the resulting schema after all migrations are applied. This is currently not easily accessible.
We should create an action that dumps the resulting schema into a docs folder after running flyway on all migrations. This action only needs to run on changes in the flyway migration dir.
Some skeleton generated by Claude:

name: Generate and Commit Flyway Schema

on:
  push:
    paths:
      - 'schema/**'
  pull_request:
    paths:
      - 'schema/**'
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  generate-schema:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    services:
      postgres:
        image: postgres:16
        env:
          POSTGRES_PASSWORD: postgres
        options: >-
          --health-cmd pg_isready
          --health-interval 10s
          --health-timeout 5s
          --health-retries 5
        ports:
          - 5432:5432

    steps:
    - name: Checkout repository
      uses: actions/checkout@v4

    - name: Run Flyway migrations
      uses: docker://flyway/flyway:10-alpine
      env:
        FLYWAY_URL: jdbc:postgresql://postgres:5432/postgres
        FLYWAY_USER: postgres
        FLYWAY_PASSWORD: postgres
      with:
        args: -locations=filesystem:/github/workspace/schema migrate

    - name: Generate schema
      run: |
        docker run --network host -v $PWD:/workspace postgres:16 \
        bash -c "PGPASSWORD=postgres pg_dump -h localhost -U postgres -d postgres --schema-only > /workspace/schema.sql"

    - name: Commit and push if changed
      run: |
        git config --global user.name 'GitHub Action'
        git config --global user.email 'action@github.com'
        git add schema.sql
        git diff --quiet && git diff --staged --quiet || (git commit -m "Update schema based on Flyway migrations" && git push)
title: Add current schema (after all migrations) to backend docs

body:
Summary
Do not store nulls when backend writes preprocessed data to sequence_entries_preprocessed_data table BUT add missing fields with null to streamed get-released-data endpoint for dependencies/users (e.g. for SILO)
Background


Currently we cannot easily add new metadata fields to the values.yaml because previously submitted sequences (that do not have the new fields) will be invalid: see e.g. #2946 for details


It seems we store a whole lot of nothing (=fields with null values) in the sequence_entries_preprocessed_data.processed_data column. We should switch to treating missing fields as having null and not saving them in the table. This would pretty much halve the size of that table.


Example processed data row:
> LOC_000CV63 |       1 |                1 | {"metadata": {"length": 17, "authors": "J.A. Mcswiggen, L. Blatt", "hostAge": null, "lineage": null, "cellLine": null, "hostRole": null, "cultureId": null, "isLabHost": null, "totalSnps": null, "geoLocCity": null, "geoLocSite": null, "hostAgeBin": null, "hostGender": null, "sampleType": null, "stopCodons": null, "bodyProduct": null, "displayName": "LOC_000CV63.1", "foodProduct": null, "frameShifts": null, "hostDisease": null, "hostTaxonId": null, "ampliconSize": null, "completeness": null, "geoLocAdmin1": null, "geoLocAdmin2": null, "insdcVersion": 1, "ncbiSourceDb": "GenBank", "exposureEvent": null, "geoLocCountry": null, "ncbiVirusName": "West Nile virus", "passageMethod": null, "passageNumber": null, "travelHistory": null, "anatomicalPart": null, "geoLocLatitude": null, "hostNameCommon": null, "ncbiUpdateDate": "2009-05-23", "ncbiVirusTaxId": 11082, "sequencingDate": null, "versionComment": null, "dehostingMethod": null, "depthOfCoverage": null, "exposureDetails": null, "exposureSetting": null, "geoLocLongitude": null, "hostHealthState": null, "ncbiReleaseDate": "2009-05-23", "sraRunAccession": null, "totalStopCodons": null, "collectionDevice": null, "collectionMethod": null, "signsAndSymptoms": null,

body:
As seen already in #2653 and #2788 we have incorrectly mapped or formatted certain insdc metadata fields to Loculus metadata fields, we also drop certain insdc metadata fields. There are no doubt more such cases.
The problem
Each time the resulting loculus metadata fields change the hash ingest calculates changes. Meaning that the version of that sequence will increase. However, we do not want to increase the version of a sample if the only changes are due to our mapping.
Suggestion
Hash ingested metadata earlier - preferably prior to any reformatting or mapping to Loculus metadata fields. This will initially cause a change of hashes and a version update (which we should probably revert), but afterwards we will not have to worry about fixing ingest metadata mappings, or using more insdc metadata fields.
Potential side effects
If an insdc metadata field that we do not use in Loculus is updated this will still cause a version increase.
title: Ingest: Potentially refactor ingest to hash metadata fields earlier?

@anna-parker and I just realized we'd independently been bothered by our swagger UI grouping being not very logical for API consumers, the current grouping is based on code organization, which is nothing API users should have to think about.
Certain backend APIs are written for public consumption (e.g. submission) while others are not really intended to be for public consumption (e.g. get original metadata). We should group things into stable and unstable APIs (private coming with no stability guarantees, if API users want them to become stable they should contact us).
Tasks:

 Indicate authentication requirements correctly
 Grouping into logical sections (submission vs. getting data vs groups vs preprocessing etc)
 Public vs private (endpoints for certain privileged users, e.g. preprocessing)
 Stable vs unstable APIs (the ones that we think people shouldn't [want to/have to] use we mark as unstable)
title: Make swagger UI sections more logical for API consumers: regroup and separate public/private endpoints

This has happened to me maybe ~3 times when running locally. I will start all pods and then I get this error from prepro when I try to submit sequences:
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:http://127.0.0.1:8079 "POST /cchf/submit-processed-data?pipelineVersion=1 HTTP/1.1" 422 None
ERROR:root:Submitting processed data failed. Traceback : Submitting processed data failed. Status code: 422
Response: {"type":"about:blank","title":"Unprocessable Entity","status":422,"detail":"The length of 'S' in 'alignedNucleotideSequences' is 1672, but it should be 100.","instance":"/cchf/submit-processed-data"}

Prepro cannot submit sequences to the backend because the backend expects sequences of length 100 (this is the length of the reference URL link - so this means that the URL has not been replaced with the actual contents),
len("[[URL:https://raw.githubusercontent.com/corneliusroemer/seqs/main/artefacts/cchf/reference_S.fasta]]")

In this specific case I updated all templates except for the database - so potentially this is an update issue?

body:
We saw some suspicious duplication of ingest data again in preview instances (see #2653). We saw this before due to concurrency of ingest jobs. We thought that adding
replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: Recreate

to the ingest deployment would prevent concurrency but maybe this isn't enough.
Some ideas how we could add a distributed lock:

Redis with Redlock: Pods can acquire a distributed lock from Redis before communicating with another pod.
Add a lock endpoint to the backend which would make the backend add a lock to the backend, sth along the lines of:


Add a lock table: with username (maybe also PID) and time of lock
Add a lock endpoint that adds an entry to the lock table for that user and otherwise returns an error if there is already an entry in the lock table for that user
Have ingest call the lock endpoint before calling get-original-metadata. Only continue with submission if the call is successful.
Have the backend clean up the lock table by removing old locks, e.g. older than 30min
title: Investigate adding a distributed lock for ingest
Add x-record-total to get-original-metadata

body:
Sequences on INSDC may be suppressed (often due to errors) or in rare circumstances withdrawn https://ena-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/release/data-availability-policy.html . Presumably in such cases they will no longer appear in our NCBI datasets download.
Suppression
The desired behaviour should be revocation of these sequences in Loculus. In cases of temporary suppression this should be followed by re-instatement. Suppression, in general, is likely to be a relatively common occurrence.
Withdrawal
The desired behaviour is a bit more debatable. At minimum sequences should be revoked but they should likely be fully deleted. (This would be high risk, so would likely involve manual intervention by database admins, and these events are likely to be rare so this need not be very automated).
title: Handling suppression / withdrawal of sequences by INSDC

body:
TLDR
I accidentally misconfigured the ingest due to inconsistent casing of config values and it took way to long to find out what's wrong.
What happened
I was setting up a Loculus instance with H5N1, i.e. a segmented organism. Some parts of the config repeats itself, so I copied it. Turns out: it didn't work. My config looks something like this:
  h5n1:
    <<: *defaultOrganismConfig
    schema:
      <<: *schema
      organismName: "Influenza A/H5N1"
      nucleotideSequences: ["seg1", "seg2", "seg3", "seg4", "seg5", "seg6", "seg7", "seg8"]
    preprocessing:
      - <<: *preprocessing
        configFile:
          <<: *preprocessingConfigFile
          log_level: DEBUG
          nextclade_dataset_name: "community/genspectrum/flu/h5n1"
          nextclade_dataset_server: "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anna-parker/nextclade_data/h5n1/data_output"
          nucleotideSequences: ["seg1", "seg2", "seg3", "seg4", "seg5", "seg6", "seg7", "seg8"]
          genes: ["PB2", "PB1", "PA", "PAX", "HA", "NA", "NP", "M1", "M2", "NS1", "NS2"]
    ingest:
      <<: *ingest
      configFile:
        taxon_id: 197911
        filter_fasta_headers: "(H5N1)"
        nucleotideSequences: ["seg1", "seg2", "seg3", "seg4", "seg5", "seg6", "seg7", "seg8"]
        nextclade_dataset_server: "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anna-parker/nextclade_data/h5n1/data_output"
        nextclade_dataset_name: "community/genspectrum/flu/h5n1"
    referenceGenomes:
      nucleotideSequences:
        - name: "seg1"
          sequence: "..."
        - ...
      genes: [...]

"Nucleotide sequences" have to be configured in 4 places, but ingest needs it in snake case whereas the others require camel case.
This has several issues / possible improvements:

Casing is inconsistent:

Some config values are camel case (organismName), some are snake case (nextclade_dataset_name)
It's even inconsistent within a single config key (nucleotide_sequences vs nucleotideSequences)

body:
Adding new metadata fields to the values.yaml causes an issue because metadata fields that was processed by prepro prior to the addition of the field does not contain the new field. The data is stored in the database and then sent to LAPIS/SILO without processing. With the new config they expect the new metadata field that does not exist.
Increasing the prepro pipeline with a metadata field addition could resolve this or the backend could process data it sends to LAPIS/SILO and add in null fields, or LAPIS/SILO prepro could do this apon data retrieval. Such a change would mean the backend would not need to store fields with null - this could be removed from prepro and save on storage cost.
title: Add the gcaAccession field  to the values.yaml

body:
One thing we're currently missing in our data model is the ability for a submitter to add publications in which they describe their sequences. This is understandable: it's not something that's commonly done for rapidly shared sequences, there the publication happens after sequences are shared.
However, there often is very much information in the papers that describe how sequences were generated.
One way we could do this is to add an array "publications" to the groups, in which groups can list their papers. Ideally, there would be one set of publications per organism, to scope it correctly. We can then add these publications to the projects that we submit to ENA - this is a very common pattern and something we should eventually do to take full advantage of the available cross-linking.
It's also something we can already import from Genbank: many sequences/projects have papers listed already, so we could surface them in sequence view.
title: Allow groups to add their papers in which they first published/describe their sequences

body:
Currently, the ingestion and deposition processes use identical taxon IDs. This approach can lead to some sequences not appearing in narrow searches.
Problem:
Ingestion and deposition processes use the same taxon ID.
Sequences may not show up in narrow searches due to this, e.g. NCBI virus might use a narrow taxon id for West Nile, so it misses the broad one
Proposed Solution:
Ingest using as broad taxon IDs as possible
Deposit using as narrow taxon IDs as possible
title: Improve Taxon ID Handling for Ingestion and Deposition
