body:
ENA expects authors to be formatted as:
3.4.10.6  The RA Line
The RA (Reference Author) lines list the authors of the paper (or other 
work) cited. All of the authors are included, and are listed in the order 
given in the paper. The names are listed surname first followed by a blank
followed by initial(s) with stops. Occasionally the initials may not 
be known, in which case the surname alone will be listed. The author names 
are separated by commas and terminated by a semicolon; they are not split 
between lines. The RA line in the example is:
RA   Oxtoby E., Dunn M.A., Pancoro A., Hughes M.A.;    
As many RA lines as necessary are included for each reference.

see https://raw.githubusercontent.com/enasequence/read_docs/master/submit/fileprep/flatfile_user_manual.txt
As we need to submit AUTHORS in this format we need to make sure that users either submit AUTHORS in this format or in another format that we can easily convert into this format.
Lists of names separated by commas will not work as both Anna Maria Smith and Sascha Baron Cohen are valid names and there is no way to know if the middle name belongs to the last name or the first name.
Previous suggestions:

standard EMBL format "surname firstname_initial1.firstname_initial2, surname firstname_initial;" if no firstname is known "surname"
custom format: "firstname, surname; firstname, surname;" if no firstname is known ", surname" can be shown on the website without commas inbetween first and surname.

We also need to reformat the data we ingest from NCBI, we receive authors from NCBI in this format: Xi,L.,Yu,X. becomes L. Xi, X. Yu and reorder the authors list (why?)
Instead we should just reformat as Xi L., Yu X.
Update:
For the moment we will start with enforcing surname, firstname; surname, first name; in prepro - this will be relatively easy to map to ENA afterwards
title: feat(preprocessing): Require formatted author list

body:
As a reviewer I'd like to have a fast and efficient review page. Currently the review page for submitters works in a non-ideal way:


it makes a big request that gets every sequence satisfying the requirements, which may be thousands leading to OOM #2884 #2881.


it also gets additional data in a lazy-load approach for everything on the page, making a lot of requests per page


also it allows filtering for errors but does not allow filtering for warnings. User should be able to find any sequences that led to warnings easily #1372


It would be great to overhaul this

allowing filtering of errors and warnings (independently, or together) [on the server side]
probably with the backend providing all the data needed to render a single paginated page of the review page in a single request (#1000).

Other related issues:

#2561
#3116
#3095

Acceptance criteria

All relevant data for the review table can be requested from the backend in a single request (requests shouldn't scale up with number of rows)
The backend doesn't crash, i.e. pagination should also be done at the DB request level
There is a way to view only sequences with warnings
All public and dev documentation adapted to new statuses, for example ripgrep "AWAITING_APPROVAL" should no longer show results (except for false positives)
title: Overhaul review page: pagination and better filtering

body:
In flowbite-react 0.10.2 the DatePicker was changed, changing the type of the value from just Date to Date | null.
We use this DatePicker for the UI to select the restriction end date for sequences. It is used once in the sequence upload, and also in the detailed sequence view, where you can edit the data use terms. In both cases a date must be there.
Some ideas I have for how to deal with this:
A) The clear button is not there, and so the value cannot be cleared, only changed to a different one, so null cannot appear anyways, so we do nothing.
B) even though technically a null value should not be settable, in the onChange handler we somehow stop the null value from being set, and instead set a default value again, then no more downstream changes should be needed.
C) even though technically a null value should not be settable, we just allow it to be set, and have the restrictedDate also be nullalbe in teh dialog, but the 'save' button is disabled if no value is set.
D) something else?

see infos here: https://github.com/themesberg/flowbite-react/pull/1190/files
title: bump flowbite-react to 0.10.2 and fix breaking DateTimePicker changes

body:
Summary
Staging is showing a duplication of all versions e.g. a sequence with v1 now has 2 v1s.
Update: Current understanding
In the sequence entries view (which we use for sending data in get-released-data) we incorrectly join on preprocessing pipeline version instead of using it as a filter - this is an old bug (which we have had since we original set up pipeline version updates)- but I overlooked it and kept it in the code when I updated the view to include external metadata.
This means get-released-data contains multiple versions of data one from each preprocessing pipeline version which we send in get-released-data.
The only thing I still don't fully understand is that SILO somehow keeps this duplication but doesn't have one version from the preprocessing version 1 and another from version 2 but sometimes one from both... odd
History
We tested rolling the changes in #2986 out to PP staging in the following steps:

Update staging loculus version to point to author formatting change
Let version bump with ingest
Run db change script (in #2986 (comment) - only changes to modify original data)
Add new preprocessing pod with new version
Let everything be processed
Remove old prepro version

Link to accession used in examples: https://staging.pathoplexus.org/seq/PP_00003PJ.1
The database is in the correct state:

However, on the website every entry is doubled:

A closer look shows that both v1 entries have authors formatted in the old method - which is a contradiction to the database (all other entries are in the new format):

body:
In LAPIS v0.3.7, the sub-lineage filter was generalized, making it possible to include sub-lineages of a lineage by appending the query with a *. In Loculus, we should incorporate this feature.
Sub-tasks include (probably not complete):

Website: add UI to send corresponding queries and allow users to decide whether to include sublineages
Deployment and config: pass the lineage tree definition file to SILO (and LAPIS?) and the backend
Backend: If a field has the new lineage type, SILO expects that only values appear that are also present in the lineage tree definition file. The backend, therefore, should validate the lineages that the preprocessing pipeline generate.
title: Lineage search field with sub-lineage queries

body:
The fact that the LAPIS client send Accept: application/json, ... headers caused a bug in #3077  when upgrading LAPIS to 0.3.6 - as from that version onwards json can be returned (though we really expect it to be plain text/fasta.
I am working around this by passing a dataFormat="FASTA" parameter, but the accept header should also be fixed, as it uses wrong semantics.
I tried something, but it didn't work: 3164731
Someone with a better understanding of our Zodios setup should have a look.
This is current main, note the highlighted accept request header:
title: LAPIS client wrongly send "Accept: application/json, ..." when it expects plaintext (FASTA)

body:
Docs and governance pages are hard to find (there are more than 30 or so in Pathoplexus). We could use Pagefind to implement a site-wide search, as discussed in pathoplexus/pathoplexus#244 I looked into this briefly: We can't use the astro-pagefind plugin because we use server side rendering. Instead, we can scrape pages with, for instance, wget to create a folder tree with render html pages. E.g.: npm run start-server & wget --mirror \ --convert-links \ --adjust-extension \ --no-parent \ --reject "*.js,*.css,*.png,*.jpg,*.jpeg,*.gif,*.ico,*.svg,*.woff,*.woff2,*.ttf" \ --exclude-directories="/seq" \ --directory-prefix=./static \ localhost:3000 We then run npx pagefind --site static/localhost:3000 And move the resulting output into the public folder: mv static/localhost:3000/pagefind public/pagefind We can then add search in the header component of every page by: including this in the html header: Adding a search div somewhere in the header nav html:
Initializing the search somewhere: Here's an (ugly) proof-of-concept: This workaround might be necessary: CloudCannon/pagefind#732 (comment) It's probably nicer to show search results in a modal, this is how Starlight (Astro docs) does it: https://github.com/withastro/starlight/blob/main/packages/starlight/components/Search.astro
title: Pagefind for search

body:
It looks like pathoplexus has curators or at least the concept of a curator (superuser?). I think the curator information should be visible on the pathogen page. There are a few reasons why I think this is important:

It humanizes pathoplexus instances, users can see clearly who is wrangling their data.
Provides an avenue to reach out to the curation team, instead of generic email (hello@...)
It boosts the profile of curators giving them credit for their work (which they can use in their cv), it also gives an incentive to curators to participate with pathoplexus
It makes pathoplexus more community driven compared to a souless data consuming organisation
It gives confidence to submitters that their data is being managed by experts instead of the faceless

There is some precedence for this, for example bigsdb has curators which are domain experts. Nextstrain and Nextclade lists authors and links to the build repo.
title: Curator information

body:
Given curators might change insdc_ingest_user submitted sequences (something that wasn't considered when writing ingest pipeline) we need to avoid the following:

Ingest gets sequence GC1234.1 from genbank, we call it PP_AAAA.1
Curator curates it, it becomes PP_AAAA.2
Ingest sees: oh no, the latest version I got from genbank is different than the latest one on PP, let’s revise: PP_AAAA.3 (with the original)

This may not actually happen with current code, it's just a possibility as it wasn't considered during development. Easy solution would be to filter out non-ingest-user-submitted sequences.
title: Ingest should not treat curator revisions as latest and revise

body:
If we curate Genbank sequences, we have to deal with the following problem:

Ingest gets sequence GC1234.1 from genbank, we call it PP_AAAA.1
Curator curates it, it becomes PP_AAAA.2
New GC1234.2 becomes available on genbank: ingest submits it as PP_AAAA.3, curation change is lost

One solution is to have a patch file that specifies a sequence (not version) and the curation changes applied to it.
When ingest revises a curated sequence, a curation bot could then reapply the patch file (potentially after curator approval).
title: How to maintain curation changes across ingest revisions

body:
Adding new metadata fields to the values.yaml causes an issue because metadata fields that was processed by prepro prior to the addition of the field does not contain the new field. The data is stored in the database and then sent to LAPIS/SILO without processing. With the new config they expect the new metadata field that does not exist.
The backend needs to be prepared for this case. It's designed to validate that processed data can be imported by SILO. So it should also catch the case when the config changes:

The backend could process data it sends to LAPIS/SILO and add in null fields, or LAPIS/SILO prepro could do this apon data retrieval. Such a change would mean the backend would not need to store fields with null - this could be removed from prepro and save on storage cost.
It could throw an error that we handle in the SILO import job - indicating that /get-released-data needs to wait for reprocessing, this would require us to wait for the preprocessing pipeline updates (when we bump the version) to rollout.

Originally posted by @fengelniederhammer and @anna-parker in #2945 (comment)
title: Modify how the backend handles "new metadata" fields e.g. when the config changes

body:
Our intended model for loculus is that there can be arbitrary field names for unprocessed (originally submitted) metadata and for final processed data.
This would allow data to be submitted with say
city : London
but for the final processed data not to contain a city but to convert everything to
latitude : xxxx
longitude: yyyy
While we mostly support this pattern there is a problem that our errrors and warnings contain only info on the source i.e. the unprocessed data that triggered an error/warning. We would also like to be able to annotate the processed fields affected. At the moment we do that, but we do so by assuming the processed field has the same name as the source field.
I raised a PR to change this specification a while back:
#932
title: Error/warnings should include both the `processed` and `unprocessed` fields it relates to

body:
From discussion in 11/11 dev meeting, we talked about allowing users to have more ways to filter sequences based on QC scores. In particular, since we 'let everything in' we should allow users to then have useful ways to filter out things that may be questionable.
There are many ways we could run with this afterwards, but as a first step, we should bring these fields in.
Current status:
Currently we have pulled in only QC fields that are 'objective' (e.g. counts of missing Nucs) and avoided those that are specific to Nextclade
However these could be not-ideal for getting an overall feel for the quality of a sequence and having one good place to filter out 'bad stuff'
Possible Objectives:

Pull in some of the 'less-objective' fields from Nextclade (ex: overall QC score)

Need a list of possible fields


Make it clear(er) these are from Nextclade and how they're generated/what they mean
Make it clear these fields may change over time (ex: a 'bad' seq may become 'good' if it's now recognised correctly as a recombinant rather than an outlier)
title: Pull in more QC fields from Nextclade

body:
Looking at our db schema, I've noticed room for improvement, e.g. foreign keys and use of enums. Here's a human review of what Claude 3.5 said about our schema. There's definitely some stuff that could be easy to add with integrity improvements that pay off in the long run:
I'll analyze the schema and suggest improvements. Here are the key areas that could be enhanced:
Missing Foreign Keys:

metadata_upload_aux_table has no FK constraint for group_id
metadata_upload_aux_table and sequence_upload_aux_table share upload_id and submission_id but have no FK relationship
external_metadata has no FK to sequence_entries for accession and version
data_use_terms_table has no FK to sequence_entries for accession
sequence_entries_preprocessed_data has no FK to sequence_entries for accession and version

Missing ENUM Types:

sequence_entries_preprocessed_data.processing_status could be an ENUM ('IN_PROCESSING', 'HAS_ERRORS', 'FINISHED')
seqset_records.type could be an ENUM
The status field in sequence_entries_view uses hardcoded strings that should be an ENUM ('APPROVED_FOR_RELEASE', 'AWAITING_APPROVAL', 'IN_PROCESSING', 'HAS_ERRORS', 'RECEIVED')
data_use_terms_type could be an ENUM

Data Integrity:

No CHECK constraints on timestamps to ensure logical order (e.g., finished_processing_at should be after started_processing_at)
No CHECK constraints on version being positive

Missing Indexes:

No index on group_id in sequence_entries despite being a foreign key

Performance:

Large JSONB columns (processed_data, external_metadata, etc.) might benefit from specific indexes on commonly queried paths
Consider partitioning large tables like sequence_entries if the data volume is high

From Claude:
Here's what I would implement first:

Add missing foreign keys

ALTER TABLE metadata_upload_aux_table 
ADD CONSTRAINT fk_metadata_upload_group 
FOREIGN KEY (group_id) REFERENCES groups_table(group_id);

ALTER TABLE external_metadata 
ADD CONSTRAINT fk_external_metadata_sequence 
FOREIGN KEY
title: Improve db schema: foreign keys, enums, etc.

body:
Originally brought up in #3125:
When we deploy a new version, Kubernetes will usually do a rolling update where it first starts the new backend and then shuts down the old one, right? If yes, this means that if we do a database migration, the old backend could write values into the database that are inconsistent with the new database version and thereby put the database into an invalid state. Can we somehow avoid having two parallel running backends (at least) if there is a database migration?
title: Prevent parallel backend instances during database migrations

body:
@fengelniederhammer raised a good point that we don't currently emit the pipeline version used to process sequences at all. This isn't great, the only way to work around this right now is to query the db.
We should somehow include the pipeline version in the response of get-released-sequences.
As it's NDJSON we can't put it in an info top-level-key unfortunately.
So we have options to:

include in HTTP header
emit as metadata field

We should probably just put it as a metadata field, that would also allow us in the future to use different pipeline versions for different organisms, something we've wanted to enable in the future to not have to reprocess everything if a single organism's Nextclade dataset is updated.
Some background discussion: https://loculus.slack.com/archives/C05G172HL6L/p1731500439841509
title: Include pipeline version in 'get-released-sequences' response somehow (header or as metadata value)

body:
I bumped processing pipeline version on virus2 to v2 and noticed the backend didn't upgrade. Inspecting the db showed that 15 sequences weren't processed by v2, these also weren't in processing or anything.
Inspection of the audit logs showed that the 15 sequences that were not getting processed had been deleted by a user while they were not yet released.
Because we don't properly use foreign key constraints (we really should, see #3201) it's possible that sequence entries disappear but the processed data remains without the db complaining (the db would have made us notice this bug much earlier and probably more bugs like that).
The fix is probably to delete all processed rows associated with an unreleased deleted entry. There might well be edge cases that will remain tricky, and until we have foreign key constraints I won't trust us to be bug free there.
We haven't noticed this because we never tried to upgrade pipeline version after someone had deleted something - kind of hard to test using our current setup. That's why foreign key constraints would be so useful. @chaoran-chen likely thought there were such constraints in place, at least in terms of the outcome of deletions - hence the case of entries are deleted, processed data is still there wasn't considered.
title: When deleting unreleased sequence entries, the entry remains in processed data table blocking pipeline upgrades

I looked briefly into the major bump of openid-client from v5 to v6. v6 is a complete rewrite. Our current auth middleware is tightly coupled to the v5 API. So upgrading is almost the same as moving to another library - unless I'm missing something.
For now it seems v5 will still get limited support, so I'll silence dependabot for now and not worry as long as things are working - dependabot should hopefully still let us know about security fixes. Though it won't let us know about other v5 bumps per dependabot/dependabot-core#9330

body:
Currently we distinguish between raw_data and processed_data which is great and allows us a fair amount of latitude to change the format in which data are outputted by bumping the preprocessing pipeline version, which changes the processed_data but not the raw_data. But sometimes we want to change the format in which we accept data and doing that requires us to go in and edit the raw_data (in a carefully designed way to maintain data integrity).
It could be good to also create a second copy of the raw data at submission (original_input_data) which is:

never edited
never directly accessed by the preprocessing pipeline, so the schema the preprocessing pipeline expects can change

Then when needs for edits were needed we would edit the raw_data but be able to manually check if the raw_data semantically matches the original_input_data.
title: Create new field: `original_input_data` that doesn't need to conform to a consistent schema (because the input schema can change)

body:
get-sequences endpoint currently does all of the following:

A) for a given group and organism: return status of all sequence entries (received/processing/processed/released)
B) for a given group and organism: return processing results for sequences in status "processed" (no issues/warnings/errors)
C) for a given group and organism and optionally filtered by status and/or processing result and optionally paginated:
              SequenceEntriesView.accessionColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.versionColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.submissionIdColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.statusColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.isRevocationColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.groupIdColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.submitterColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.organismColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.submittedAtTimestampColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.errorsColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.warningsColumn,
              SequenceEntriesView.processingResultColumn,
              DataUseTermsTable.dataUseTermsTypeColumn,
              DataUseTermsTable.restrictedUntilColumn,



Parts of it are used in the following places by the website (afaict):

Submission portal: uses A) to show how many sequences are awaiting review [the fact that getSequences returns so much more was behind that pages slowness, fixed in a kind of hacky way by #3279, by simply not asking for any of the voluminous data
Review page: uses A) and B) to show counts of how many sequences are in which states and uses only the accession and version columns of C) to be able to then query individual entries

I couldn't find anything that uses all of the other columns: in particular the data use terms seem to be joined for no reason. There's no user of it.
It looks like we could serve the current website much leanly by:

Having an endpoint that simply serves aggregate stats for a given group and organism and optionally returns accessions but not
title: Is getSequences endpoint really used in full by anything? It seems no longer fit for purpose: should it be replaced?

body: At the moment the ArgoCD deployments are structured as a single pod per branch, which has 5 containers with all the different components. A better approach (closer to what the real deployment would look like) is probably one where each of these containers are their own deployment. But in order for these containers to be in their own deployment but to link up properly one would want them to be in their own namespace. The problem with having them in their own namespace was that we need a secret to pull images from GHCR, and I didn't figure out how to inject that secret into each namespace. We should do that injection with sealed secrets - the secret will be stored in the open on GitHub but in a totally safe encrypted form.
title: ArgoCD: use sealed secrets

body:
This ticket is about which features we would like to have for revised and revoked sequences from the data user's perspective as well as how to model it in SILO. I'm putting both together because they are largely coupled, especially since the way we model it in SILO directly determines the user experience for API users.
(Background: The implementation of revision/revocation in the backend is described here: https://github.com/pathoplexus/pathoplexus/blob/3abbd9f7168feaad110c0fb99a59290788eede7f/backend/docs/runtime_view.md#revision)
Here's my proposal:
Features:

On the details page of a sequence, if there is a newer version of the sequence, the user should see a note saying that there is a newer version and linking to the newest version.
On the details page of a sequence, if there is a newer version of the sequence and the newest version is a "revocation entry", the user should see a note saying that the sequence was revoked and linking to the newest version.
On the details page of a sequence, if it is a "revocation entry", the page should show the revocation date.
Not sure: What do we show on the details page of a sequence, if there is a newer version of the sequence that is a "revocation entry" but the newest version is not a "revocation entry"? I.e., if the sequence was revoked and then unrevoked? Proposal: This is a very rare case and for simplicity, we don't add special handling and let it be covered by (1): i.e., we just link to the newest version but don't mention revocation.
The search only queries the latest versions and non-revoked data.
Through the API/bulk download, people can get all revisions and revocation entries. People should be able to see when a sequence was revised and revoked (and unrevoked).

In SILO, we have the following special columns:


sequenceIdWithVersion - the primary key


sequenceId


version


isRevocation - indicates that this is a revocation entry. The entry doesn't contain any sequence and sequence-related metadata. It does cont
title: Revision and revocation design & SILO modeling

Edit (Chaoran):
Decision: Let's change the URL to /seq

It's great that we are centralising URLs (https://github.com/pathoplexus/pathoplexus/pull/428). But still we are unlikely to want to update URLs after launch so it's good to think through now what the best URL scheme is. Ideally URLs should be short and meaningful.
My proposal would be:

/seq/[sequence_id] (shows latest version, but without redirect? One can also argue it should just redirect to the latest version.)
/seq/[sequence_id].version (shows specific version)
/seq/[sequence_id].fa or /seq/[sequence_id].[version].fa provide Fasta output. (I think this would be really nice to have and shouldn't be hard to implement)
title: Sequence URLs

Possible proposal, ids look likePB_A32E7G2, comprising:

A maintainer-customised string prefix for IDs per-instance. Probably this will be something like e.g. PB_ (but I don't think we need to mandate the underscore).
This is followed by a unique ID per sequence entry, [and a final checksum character]
Unique IDs are a base 36 "number" (i.e. a number expressed with characters 0-9 and letters A-Z, could be A32E7G - at that length we would get up to 2 billion sequences - but initially lengths would be much shorter)
[The final checksum character is the base 36 modulus]

body:
This is to discuss how we can support multiple pathogens on the backend side. Originally (at the very beginning of the project), I thought that we might want to launch one instance of the backend per pathogen (just as we do with SILO/LAPIS). Now, considering the architecture of our backend, I think that this doesn't make sense and that it would be easy to add multi-pathogen support.
URLs
I assume that there won't really be a need to request or submit data of different pathogens in one request. For example, we don't expect/won't want to allow users to make submissions that contain sequence entries of different pathogens. Also, each preprocessing pipeline will probably be dedicated to only one pathogen. Thus, I suggest having the pathogen name as a path parameter:
/{pathogen}/submit
/{pathogen}/extract-unprocessed-data
...

Config
I am not sure how to best design a configuration system and organize configuration files. Just one thought inspired by Nginx/LaTeX/...: In Nginx, there is one (root) config file - (usually) nginx.conf (see example file), and it can include individual files or whole directories. There are common structures such as having one config file per site but in principle, everything can also be written in a single config file. Is that maybe a good approach for us going forward?
Database
Internally, we only need to add a column pathogen to the sequences table.
What's the primary key then? See below.
Accession
Option 1: Sequence entries across pathogens within an instance share the same accession space.
Option 2: Sequence entries of different pathogens have separate accession spaces. They could have different prefixes.
In favor of option 1:

A prefix stands for the instance and helps people to recognize an instance.
It avoids having a lot of different prefixes.
It is what INSDC do.

In favor of option 2:

People can recognize the pathogen from the prefix.
Not sure if this is relevant.. It would make it easier to merge instances that hold different patho
title: Backend multi-pathogen support
Deploy main branch through argocd

body:
We need to add two endpoints that the INSDC upload bot can call, similar to the ones we have for the preprocessing pipeline.
Database extensions
We need to extend our database to store the INSDC upload status, INSDC accession, and potentially upload error messages/warnings. Suggestion:
Add the following columns to the sequences table:

insdc_upload_status: NOT_READY_FOR_UPLOAD (e.g., because it's embargoed) | READY_FOR_UPLOAD | UPLOADING | UPLOADED | UPLOAD_FAILED
insdc_accession
insdc_upload_errors: not sure what type of errors might occur...

Endpoints
Not sure what the good names would be, but a suggestion: (1) /{organism}/extract-data-for-insdc-upload and (2) /{organism}/submit-insdc-upload-data
Endpoint (1) would have a numberOfSequenceEntries-parameter again and return at least our accession+version, submitter information, the preprocessed metadata, and nucleotide sequences. Endpoint (2) would take our accession+version and insdc_upload_status, insdc_accession, and potentially insdc_upload_errors.
New submission vs revision and revocation
Should endpoint (1) only return entirely new sequences or also sequences that were revised or revoked? Or do we want to have separate endpoints to extract revised and revoked sequences that are ready for upload?
(cc @corneliusroemer)
title: Endpoints for the INSDC upload bot

body:
Pathoplexus will be two things:

an instance of Loculus, providing a database
a social/political project which needs: pages about governance, documentation, policies, funding, etc.

The latter are not part of loculus, but will be housed on a shared website. We need some way of allowing this. I previously raised this in https://github.com/orgs/loculus-project/discussions/112 but I think it's reaching the point of being worth an Issue.
My own view is that we really want to allow ourselves quite a bit of flexibility in the Pathoplexus-specific pages. I would like the option to e.g. embed a Twitter widget for example, and to have photos of the Governance people. And I'd really like to keep open the possibility of arbitrary HTML, to e.g. have a Nextstrain build or something.
I've come to the conclusion that the best way to do this is to have the pathoplexus website have its own Docker image. We would have a repo which would contain a website directory which would simply be copied on top of the loculus website directory and then be built as an image. This directory would contain only the pathoplexus-specific pages (and potentially subpages used as includes).
I'm happy to implement this in Feb - just wanted to capture the issue while we're in the mode of capturing Issues. Open to discussion if people don't like this way of going about it, but I do think it has the fewest drawbacks.
title: Overlay image for pathoplexus website

body:
Sometimes, we would like to update and rerun the pre-processing pipeline (due to new clade designations, improvements, adding new fields, etc.). Here's a proposal for the implementation:

The backend has a current_preprocessing_version and a staging_preprocessing_version.
The administrator can start reprocessing by setting a new staging_preprocessing_version.
We add the following columns to the sequence_entries table:

preprocessing_pipeline_version - Stores the pipeline version of processed_data
staging_processed_data, staging_errors, stating_warnings, staging_preprocessing_pipeline_version


When calling the /extract-unprocessed-data endpoint, the preprocessing pipeline has to state its version. The endpoint also returns data if the version is the staging_preprocessing_version and the sequence has not been reprocessed.
When a preprocessing pipeline submits preprocessed data through /submit-processed-data, it must also state its version. Based on the version, the data is stored either in the "production" fields or in the staging fields.
If a new preprocessing pipeline reports an error for a sequence that has already been released, the administrator (and the curators?) gets a notification. It is not possible/safe to release the reprocessed data until the issue has been resolved.
Once the new preprocessing pipeline has caught up and all sequences in the Awaiting_approval or Approved_for_release state are processed by the new version, the content in the staging fields gets swapped in.

What do you think about this approach? Do you think that we need to implement it before the MVP launch or can it be added afterwards? (I'm in favor of adding it afterwards.)
title: Reprocessing

It can happen that the preprocessing pipeline crashes while it processes sequences. Right now, when the preprocessing pipeline doesn't send anything back to the backend, sequences will be "in processing" forever.
We've discussed that we need to move sequences for which this is the case back to "received" after a configurable time.
Something to think through: what happens if the preprocessing pipeline submits something after the backend has timed out a sequence and moved it back to "received": we should probably just send an error to the processing pipeline and ignore that sequence from a backend perspective. It just has to be preprocessed again.
title: Backend to put sequences "in processing" back to "received" after configurable timeout

body:
A public loculus instance that sends data to INSDC must be able to authenticate users somehow - we cannot allow anonymous submissions. Otherwise anyone on the internet can submit sequences to INSDC and upload garbage.
In discussion with @bh-ethz  and @chaoran-chen  we discussed two options:
a) Email allowlist: certain domains allow us to identify users, e.g. university email addresses. If someone signs up with such an email address and they confirm ownership of the email address this should be sufficient trust to allow them to submit.
b) For users who do not have an email address on the allowlist, admins can give manual approval
Given the current setup, where we give accessions as soon as a submitter starts the submission, we should not allow even that step for anonymous accounts, as we can otherwise run out of accessions. This could be softened if we had a way to rate limit anonymous accounts, e.g. allow submission of at most 100-1000 sequences without being approved for submission (via allowlist or manually).
A rate limit is probably not a bad idea in general, even for users who are allowlisted. Depending on a pathogen, there's a clear max size of submission that should be very unlikely to ever be exceed. E.g. it's unlikely anyone will ever submit more than 10k mpox sequences, given there are only 7.5k sequences on Genbank. The issue with a rate limit is that it does require quite some extra backend work, whereas an allowlist should be straightforward.
title: Make ability to submit dependent on having allowlisted email domain or admin approval or rate limit

This is definitely not urgent and something for well post-MVP
But it could also pay off for certain use cases like storing all public SARS-CoV-2 sequences. These are uncompressed around 150-200GB at the moment, which even with 1Gbps uplink would take half an hour.
Allowing compression would also save ingress costs.

I was surprised to find that the backend didn't validate the presence of required fields (per the values.yaml schema) in the metadata.
Theo was able to successfully submit a sequence with the only metadata being {"hello": "world"}, despite main's values.yaml currently requiring collection_date:

  
    
      loculus/kubernetes/loculus/values.yaml
    
    
        Lines 80 to 82
      in
      7733ab3
    
  
  
    

        
          
           - name: collection_date 
        

        
          
             type: date 
        

        
          
             required: true 
        
    
  


I guess my intuition about this was wrong - and we appear to have decided that the backend doesn't check presence of required fields. The specification is unclear about what the backend actually checks. It would be very helpful for the purpose of writing the pipeline to know what guarantees I can rely on from the backend: what's checked and what isn't? Will metadata always be a single level str -> str mapping but potentially empty, or can it also be nested?
title: Backend does not check if field with `required: true` in schema is actually present in metadata

body:
This issue is to discuss how we should implement the upload/receival of user submissions, i.e. the way of the data from the submitter's device (browser or CLI) to our (relational core) database. The main challenge is that the uploads can be huge and I think that our software should be able to accept arbitrarily large uploads. The admin can/should (of course) limit the maximum size.
Some thoughts:

Do we want to be able to resume after a short connection disruption? Maybe we can use tus.io or resumable.js Not relevant for MVP.
What are the compression formats that we should support? zip, zstd, gz, and xz?
Should the user also be able to upload large uncompressed files? If they do, maybe we can compress them in the browser/CLI software first? Or do we (for now) simply reject large uncompressed files (e.g., above 1 GB)?
We need to have protection again zip bombs.
The implementation needs to be memory-efficient (we shouldn't hold multiple GBs of data in RAM for one upload).
title: Receiving (potentially large) uploads

body:
As a sequence owner, I want to be able to change the data use terms of my sequences on the website.
We thought about implementing it on the user sequences page:

Two options came to our minds:

add a button to each sequence line to change the license of this entry
add a button on the top right (next to "Revoke") to change the license of all selected entries.

The backend endpoint accepts a list of accessions.
title: Change data use term in bulk

body:
When an logged out user navigates to a group page like https://main.loculus.org/group/a - they still see that the group exists, but not more. The console will show 401 Unauthorized, but this isn't reflected on the website itself.

Related to #985
title: Show meaningful page to non-group-member on `/group/GROUPNAME` page

body:
When uploading all mpox sequences, the requests fails but not with one of the correct HTTP error codes, but with some SSL thing instead:
urllib3.exceptions.SSLError: EOF occurred in violation of protocol (_ssl.c:2406)

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/corneliusromer/micromamba/envs/py12/lib/python3.12/site-packages/requests/adapters.py", line 486, in send
    resp = conn.urlopen(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/corneliusromer/micromamba/envs/py12/lib/python3.12/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 847, in urlopen
    retries = retries.increment(
              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/corneliusromer/micromamba/envs/py12/lib/python3.12/site-packages/urllib3/util/retry.py", line 515, in increment
    raise MaxRetryError(_pool, url, reason) from reason  # type: ignore[arg-type]
    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='backend-940-query-metadata-for-re.loculus.org', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /mpox/submit?groupName=insdc_ingest_group&dataUseTermsType=OPEN (Caused by SSLError(SSLEOFError(8, 'EOF occurred in violation of protocol (_ssl.c:2406)')))

Repro:

Upload these sequences https://loculus.slack.com/files/U05FBBSP02F/F06K13HNGV6/mpox_7200.tar.zst

Instead of SSL error, I should get:
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 413 Client Error: Request Entity Too Large for url: https://backend-940-query-metadata-for-re.loculus.org/mpox/submit?groupName=insdc_ingest_group&dataUseTermsType=OPEN

which is what I get when I upload 1k rather than 7k mpox sequences.
title: When uploading too many sequences (7k mpox) I get error SSL error "violation of protocol"

body:
Backend logging seems to be quite limited at the moment: we log every request from the preprocessing pipeline, but I can't find anything about actual submissions, e.g. the following situations are definitely log-worthy:

When submitting: returning 413, request too large
When submitting: erroring in some non-orderly way #996

I guess having all the preprocessing requests in logs as info is ok, but there should be more consistent logging of other parts of the backend.
title: Improved INFO level backend logging for observability

body:
This enables preprocessing in helm for codespaces. When I included this is in a PR before @fengelniederhammer sensibly pointed out it would break the ability to run the e2e tests in codespaces - but I'm the only person using the codespaces atm as far as I know and I personally only run these tests from CI.
I have tried running ./deploy.py helm uninstall and then redeploying with processing enabled after startup, but this yields an error message about the groups table already existing or something. In general I think the ability to get data into the DB is more important than the ability to run the E2E tests from the codespace so I think this makes sense as the lesser of two evils. In due course we can make multiple codespace configs.
title: Enable preprocessing in helm for codespaces

body:
Bumps jsdom from 23.2.0 to 24.0.0.

Release notes
Sourced from jsdom's releases.

Version 24.0.0
This release reverts our selector engine back to nwsapi. As discussed in #3659, the performance regressions from @asamuzakjp/dom-selector turned out to be higher than anticipated. In the future, we can revisit @asamuzakjp/dom-selector after it reaches nwsapi's performance on the two real-world benchmarks provided by the community.
Since reverting to nwsapi causes several functionality regressions, e.g. removing :has() support, we've decided to make this a major version.
Additionally:

Small fixes to edge-case behavior of the following properties: input.maxLength, input.minLength, input.size, progress.max, tableCell.colSpan, tableCell.rowSpan, tableCol.span, textArea.cols, textArea.maxLength, textArea.minLength, textArea.rows.




Changelog
Sourced from jsdom's changelog.

24.0.0
This release reverts our selector engine back to nwsapi. As discussed in #3659, the performance regressions from @asamuzakjp/dom-selector turned out to be higher than anticipated. In the future, we can revisit @asamuzakjp/dom-selector after it reaches nwsapi's performance on the two real-world benchmarks provided by the community.
Since reverting to nwsapi causes several functionality regressions, e.g. removing :has() support, we've decided to make this a major version.
Additionally:

Small fixes to edge-case behavior of the following properties: input.maxLength, input.minLength, input.size, progress.max, tableCell.colSpan, tableCell.rowSpan, tableCol.span, textArea.cols, textArea.maxLength, textArea.minLength, textArea.rows.

Fixed

Remove regex lookbehind

Remove lookbehind from regex for older browser support (blakeembrey/change-case@6512635)

Add split option to change-case

Added a split option to the change-case transform functions to allow for customization on how words are extracted from input

The package exports are now default instead of import to fix some tooling that doesn't work properly with import

body:
This PR creates a basic Astro setup (closes #3) with the following features:

A page (at /sequences) that fetches the sequence accessions of all Swiss SARS-CoV-2 sequences from the open LAPIS (version 1) instance

The sequence list is paginated (#8)


Sequence details pages (at /sequences/[accession]) that show the metadata of a sequence (#6)
The fields are read from a config file.
Tailwindcss
Playwright test setup
GitHub CI with test execution, linting, and Docker container building

I am not closing issues #6 and #8 as I don't consider them as part of this PR. The PR does not contain any styling or proper tests. The related code serves only as an example but is not a proper implementation of these features.
title: feat(website): add basic setup

Updates org.postgresql:postgresql from 42.7.1 to 42.7.2

Release notes
Sourced from org.postgresql:postgresql's releases.

v42.7.2
Security
CVE-2024-1597 and Security Advisory addressed. The vulnerability occurs only in non-default preferQueryMode=simple mode and only if a negative place holder -? is used. See the security advisory for details
What's Changed

perf: avoid autoboxing bind indexes by @​bokken in pgjdbc/pgjdbc#1244
add: Add PasswordUtil for encrypting passwords client side by @​sehrope in pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3082
refactor: document that encodePassword will zero out the password array, and remove driver's default encodePassword by @​vlsi in pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3084
change: Use simple query for isValid. Using Extended query sends two messages by @​davecramer in pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3101

Full Changelog: pgjdbc/pgjdbc@REL42.7.1...REL42.7.2



Changelog
Sourced from org.postgresql:postgresql's changelog.

[42.7.2] (2024-02-21 08:23:00 -0500)
Security

security: SQL Injection via line comment generation, it is possible in SimpleQuery mode to generate a line comment by having a placeholder for a numeric with a -
such as -?. There must be second placeholder for a string immediately after. Setting the parameter to a -ve value creates a line comment.
This has been fixed in this version fixes CVE-2024-1597. Reported by Paul Gerste. See the security advisory for more details. This has been fixed in versions 42.7.2, 42.6.1 42.5.5, 42.4.4, 42.3.9, 42.2.28.jre7. See the security advisory for work arounds.

Changed

fix: Use simple query for isValid. Using Extended query sends two messages checkConnectionQuery was never ever set or used, removed [PR #3101](pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3101)
perf: Avoid autoboxing bind indexes by @​bokken in [PR #1244](pgjdbc/pgjdbc#1244)
refactor: Document that encodePassword will zero out

body:
Summary
Bypass building docker images when all relevant input files have not changed (akin to NixOS)

Calculate hash of all files relevant for docker build
Add that hash as a tag to all built images
For future builds, only run builds when there's no docker image with the input file dir hash

This way, docker builds are only done when necessary. You change website only in a commit, then no need to build a new backend docker image.
Docker build times were roughly:

1.30min for Nextclade, though sometimes only 30s if (separate from this PR) docker cache hit
2-4min for website
2-3min for backend

The bypass workflow completes in 20s.
Benefit is not just that we save a few Github action minutes, but also that preview builds are up much faster when only config is changed, this should be particularly helpful for @theosanderson
title: Retag images to reduce time spent on recomputing unchanged docker images

body:
resolves #1026 and more

preview URL: https://organism.loculus.org/
Summary
This PR makes two changes:

it renames instances in helm Values to organisms, in line with our nomenclature. This was a backlog item.
it renames the organisms in the default Values.yaml to defaultOrganisms. It only uses this if organisms is unset. Without this, if we make a new instance and set organisms appropriately, the dummy-organism, etc., gets added in too. It would be nice to do this with helm templates but I couldn't make that work.
title: Rename instances to organisms and more

body:
Copy steps from update-argocd-metadata.yml
Reason is that timeout of 480s is sometimes not enough, as here: https://github.com/loculus-project/loculus/actions/runs/8160168762/job/22306170308 where website image build took 6min and pods weren't ready before timeout.
I initially deleted the waits because they weren't exhaustive - now that we have the waits in update-argocd workflow anyways, copy them over here.

body:
E2E tests take the longest of anything. That's partly because we run them on 3 different browsers. Nowadays, breakages on individual browsers are pretty rare, and they are generally more visual breakages that tests might pick up. Let's only run E2E tests on chrome, apart from after we merge to main?
This E2E ran in 11 mins, which is substantially faster than before
title: Run e2e tests just on chrome except on main branch
Allow forcing of testing on all browsers

Preview: https://seq-page-revocation.loculus.org/
Summary

Add a revocation button to the bottom of the sequence details page if the sequence is from one of my groups
Make it redirect to review page
Make review page display revocations awaiting approval
Make approval endpoint accept revocations awaiting approval
Bring in react-toastify and use it to display error messages here:


(We have what is IMO a bad pattern of using "ManagedErrorFeedback", which requires us to store in react state the current error condition. The react-toastify approach is much simpler and just lets us say toast(errorMessage) without managing any state. I think we should gradually transition to that. (Or to a version of our own feedback element that works in the same way). I don't want to add another example of the IMO not great pattern that we'll have to adapt later.)



Screenshot

(design courtesy Chaoran!)
PR Checklist


 All necessary documentation has been adapted.
 The implemented feature is covered by an appropriate test.
I tried really hard to add an E2E test for this, spending more time attempting this than doing the non-testing implementation. As far as I can see it's really hard with our current pattern. We don't create separate sequences in LAPIS for each testing user. I think we generally need to rework our testing set up, probably to allow tests to run in parallel, and to allow us to set arbitrary data into LAPIS easily on a per-user basis. Here is an issue for that: #1315

Minor Changes


#10136 9cd84bd19b92fb43ae48809f575ee12ebd43ea8f Thanks @​matthewp! - Changes the default behavior of transition:persist to update the props of persisted islands upon navigation. Also adds a new view transitions option transition:persist-props (default: false) to prevent props from updating as needed.
Islands which have the transition:persist property to keep their state when using the <ViewTransitions /> router will now have their props updated upon navigation. This is useful in cases where the component relies on page-specific props, such as the current page title, which should update upon navigation.
For example, the component below is set to persist across navigation. This component receives a products props and might have some internal state, such as which filters are applied:
<ProductListing transition:persist products={products} />
Upon navigation, this component persists, but the desired pr

When a route does not match in SSR deployments, your adapter may show a platform-specific 404 page instead of running Astro's SSR code. In these cases, you may still need to add a 404.astro or fallback route with spread params, or use a routing configuration option if your adapter provides one.

Minor Changes


#10206 dc87214141e7f8406c0fdf6a7f425dad6dea6d3e Thanks @​lilnasy! - Allows middleware to run when a matching page or endpoint is not found. Previously, a pages/404.astro or pages/[...catch-all].astro route had to match to allow middleware. This is now not necessary.
When a route does not match in SSR deployments, your adapter may show a platform-specific 404 page instead of running Astro's SSR code. In these cases, you may still need to add a 404.astro or fallback route with spread params, or use a routing configuration option if your adapter provides one.


#9960 c081adf998d30419fed97d8fccc11340cdc512e0 Thanks @​StandardGage! - Allows passing any props to the <Code /> component


#10102 e3f02f5fb1cf0dae3c54beb3a4af3dbf3b06abb7 Thanks @​bluwy! - Adds a new experimental.directRenderScript configuration option which provides a more reliable strategy to prevent scripts from being executed in pages where they are not used.
This replaces the experimental.optimizeHoistedScript flag introduced in v2.10.4 to prevent unused components' scripts from being included in a page unexpectedly. That experimental option no longer exists and must be removed from your configuration, whether or not you enable directRenderScript:
// astro.config.mjs
import { defineConfig } from 'astro/config';
export default defineConfig({
experimental: {


  optimizeHoistedScript: true,





  directRenderScript: true

}
});

With experimental.directRenderScript configured, scripts are now directly rendered as declared in Astr

body:
resolves #1161, resolves #1034

preview URL: https://reviewcounts.loculus.org
Get the review page to display counts of sequences in different statuses and to allow toggling their visibility. Cache the old result and used it when grayed out when loading to avoid jumping to a totally white loading screen.
To get this to work we had to add an initialStatusFilter to the getSequences call, which is applied initially, and applies to the counts. Then the second main filter is applied after the counts.

Remaining issue: #1372
title: Review page: Display counts of different sequences statuses and allow filtering and improve loading CLS and restyle buttons

body:
https://reviewpage-redesign.loculus.org/

Header becomes sticky and we lose the shadow and borders on "cards".
Also we fix a bug in the previous version by adding an additional initialStatusFilter which is applied to counts: previously we were also retrieving counts for all released sequences. I'm open to suggestions on how to do this differently
title: Reviewpage redesign

Bumps astro from 2.9.6 to 2.10.1.

Release notes
Sourced from astro's releases.

astro@2.10.1
Patch Changes


#7935 6035bb35f Thanks @​natemoo-re! - Properly handle routing when multiple slashes are present in the request by collapsing them to a single /


#7936 4b6deda36 Thanks @​matthewp! - Export createTransitionScope for the runtime


Updated dependencies [6035bb35f]:

@​astrojs/internal-helpers@​0.1.2



astro@2.10.0
Minor Changes


#7861 41afb8405 Thanks @​matthewp! - Persistent DOM and Islands in Experimental View Transitions
With viewTransitions: true enabled in your Astro config's experimental section, pages using the <ViewTransition /> routing component can now access a new transition:persist directive.
With this directive, you can keep the state of DOM elements and islands on the old page when transitioning to the new page.
For example, to keep a video playing across page navigation, add transition:persist to the element:
<video controls="" autoplay="" transition:persist>
  <source
    src="https://ia804502.us.archive.org/33/items/GoldenGa1939_3/GoldenGa1939_3_512kb.mp4"
    type="video/mp4"
  />
</video>
This <video> element, with its current state, will be moved over to the next page (if the video also exists on that page).
Likewise, this feature works with any client-side framework component island. In this example, a counter's state is preserved and moved to the new page:
<Counter count={5} client:load transition:persist />
See our View Transitions Guide to learn more on usage.


Patch Changes


#7821 c00b6f0c4 Thanks @​ottomated! - Fixes an issue that prevents importing 'astro/app'


#7917 1f0ee494a Thanks @​bluwy! - Prevent integration hooks from re-triggering if the server restarts on config change, but the config fails to load.


#7901 00cb28f49 Thanks @​bluwy! - Improve sourcemap generation and performance


#7911 c264be349 Thanks @​martrapp! - fix for #7882 by setting state in page navigation (view transitions)

body:
preview URL: https://feat-mutation-badges.loculus.org/seq/LOC_000001Y.1
Summary
Add mutation badge React components for nuc and aa mutations.
This is a simplified version of what's there in Nextclade or Covariants. I had to port it from styled-components to tailwind.
Badge segments are colored dynamically, depending on a character or gene name. I use style attr to handle that.
Additionally, the text is being rendered of light or dark color depending on the contrast ratio relative to background color. I had to add polished NPM package to calculate contrast ratio.
Notes:


There is no fixed list of genes/CDSes avaialble, so it's not immediately possible to render stable (recognizable) gene/CDS colors, which may increase readablity of aa badges significantly. In Nextclade the list is provided from "backend" and then gene index in the list is used to select color from a fixed list of colors (with index wrap on overflow), and in Covariants the list is static, as it only deals with SC2. In both cases, color palette is taken from nextstrain.org "Nucleotide diversity of genome" panel, as something we are the most accustomed to in Nextstrain organization. In Loclulus I decided to use color hash algorithm to generate colors from gene name strings for now. If backend could provide this data, then UX could be further improved.


It seems that DataTable.astro is only able to render values that are strings or numbers. I don't immediately see how the badges can be incorporated there without hacks. I need a bit more details of what's planned for this component. So for now I just temporarily added some hardcoded badges above the table as a showcase.


From a quick look, I found that backend currently provides mutations in string format, e.g. A123G. This means that these strings need to be parsed in order to extract gene, position, and ref and query characters. In Covariants this is done using regex like that. It's a bit of a hairy adventure though. So if backend could precompute and
title: feat(web): add mutation badges

relates to  #1471, #862

preview URL: https://docspages.loculus.org/docs/data-use-terms
Summary
Adds the docs markdown files - which we developed on pathoplexus - to Loculus. Adds a placeholder for data use terms and links to it from various places which had dummy URLs. (In time we probably want to make the fact that the links appear, and maybe even the license form, not a default part of Loculus unless enabled).
If we go for additional Astro docs, then we may want to rename "docs" here to some other word, for the stuff that is non-technical documentation which should probably live on the main site.
title: Add docs pages and placeholder for data-use-terms

body:
I think these red buttons are too bright, and look less professional.

We could make them darker (red-600, or red-700). But I think given we prompt for confirmation we can just make them primary colored like the other buttons, which is what this PR does.
title: Red buttons -> primary color on groups page

body:
Resolves #775
See discussion: https://loculus.slack.com/archives/C05G172HL6L/p1711384380415999
preview URL: https://silo-hash.loculus.org
Summary

Use hash instead of line count to test for equality of silo preprocessing input files
If hashes equal, can just use old data as new data
If hashes unequal, remove old data, run preprocessing on new data
Apply shellcheck recommendation, separating dirs from args with --
Add todo #1489 once fixed upstream

Ideally, we would not download everything from the backend, but somehow get some "last modified" timestamp from backend. For small data like pathoplexus this doesn't matter. For SARS-CoV-2 it would avoid having to stream 400GB from backend to silo preprocessing.
Tests
I tested/developed using this test setup:

body:
I think we need a short discussion how exactly we want to log.
What have been done:


for the server: winston is used to pipe logs into a local file that can be retrieved/downloaded/deleted via /admin route


for the direct server output, I created a new npm script the redirects and pipes the output into a log file. The log file location is hardcoded in this case.


for the client: an POST-endpoint is created where client-logs can be send to. These logs will be appended to the local file


deploying via docker locally works as expected. (docker build -t website . && DOCKER_IMAGE_NAME=website docker-compose up)

Deployment on netlify breaks since they deploy serverless functions and the simple approach (plain old log-files) cannot work.
I left the hardcoded log folder as is, but this breaks the admin endpoint on netlify.



https://develop.sentry.dev/self-hosted/ would be an alternative, but is another service that has to be deployed and maintained. I have set up a self-hosted sentry instance. It comes with 24 different container (it starts a kafka, postgres, redis,...) and naively I would suggest our requirements for infrastructure would more than double

body:
preview URL: https://1157-dont-use-group-name.loculus.org/
Summary

Getting rid of the "table providers"

Split sequence compression/decompression and DB access
Simplify the code
Less unnecessary "organism" passing around - using Exposed as it's supposed to be used.
More explicit decompression (a forgotten slice to exclude the data columns otherwise has large performance impact)

I started this as part of ##1157 but decided that it's worth its own PR.
Screenshot

PR Checklist

 The implemented feature is covered by an appropriate test.

Error message:
Parsing error: ESLint was configured to run on `<tsconfigRootDir>/astro.config.mjs` using `parserOptions.project`: /users/corneliusromer/code/loculus-bun/website/tsconfig.eslint.json
However, that TSConfig does not include this file. Either:
- Change ESLint's list of included files to not include this file
- Change that TSConfig to include this file
- Create a new TSConfig that includes this file and include it in your parserOptions.project
See the typescript-eslint docs for more info: https://typescript-eslint.io/linting/troubleshooting#i-get-errors-telling-me-eslint-was-configured-to-run--however-that-tsconfig-does-not--none-of-those-tsconfigs-include-this-fileeslint

body:
The easiest way to do quick local website dev is to point use main (or another branch) for everything but website code.
I've edited the runtime_config.json multiple times to do this, so many times that I think it would be good to have an example config to quickly use. Maybe there's a better place for this, let me know.

body:
preview URL: https://int-str.loculus.org
Summary

Kotlin: Rename backend config metadata schema type integer to int to be in sync with website config. Otherwise, with the current shared backend/frontend config logic we can't actually use integer typed values.
Website/backend config: Add comment to each config referring to each other to make it easier in future to remember they need to be kept in sync - at some point someone decided to call on integer and the other int, also double was added for backend but not for website, see #1566 for the bug that could have been discovered earlier had we been more explicit about the configs needing to be in sync.
Nextclade preprocessing: cast fields to appropriate JSON type before uploading, e.g. int/float, make this configurable
values.yaml config schema: Make it possible to configure what JSON type a processed data type should be

Screenshot
Nothing changes visibly, but we can now do things like integer filters #1494
title: feat(processing): use `int` consistently in config, add casting to int/float int processing pipeline

I changed the paths to the submission-related pages. The submit, revise, review unreleased sequences, and view released sequences pages are now all under /submission/{groupId}/. The edit page is under /submission/edit/. The submit, revise, and view released sequences pages now also have the same group selector that was introduced in #1520.
This prepares for #1038.

body:
Bumps gradle/actions from 3 to 321.

Release notes
Sourced from gradle/actions's releases.

v3.2.1
The recent update to use com.develocity.gradle plugin resulted in many deprecation warnings being triggered by the init-scripts bundled with this action. This patch release updates these init-scripts to avoid these deprecation warnings.
What's Changed

Fix Develocity deprecation warnings in v3.2.1 (#126) by #129

Full Changelog: gradle/actions@v3.2.0...v3.2.1
v3.2.0
Changelog
General improvements

[NEW] Support authentication for plugin repositories (#31)
[FIX] Improve rendering of build results table with long values (#35)

Improvements to Dependency Submission

[FIX] Do not attempt to resolve dependency configurations that are excluded via env var (#107)

Improvements to Develocity injection

[NEW] Use com.develocity.gradle plugin version 3.17 by default
[NEW] Can configure capture of file-fingerprint (#58)
[FIX] Reduce log-level of messages emitted by Develocity injection (#60)

Note
Release includes v3.2.0 of gradle/actions/setup-gradle and gradle/actions/dependency-submission.
Available under the v3 version tag.
The gradle/actions/setup-gradle action supersedes gradle/gradle-build-action.
The gradle/gradle-build-action@v3.2.0 version will be released in parallel, and will delegate to this release of gradle/actions/setup-gradle.
Full Changelog: gradle/actions@v3.1.0...v3.2.0
v3.1.0
This release provides more Gradle output when running with actions debug logging, and fixes some minor issues with gradle/actions/dependency-submission.
Changelog

[NEW] Support ACTIONS_STEP_DEBUG mode (#6)
[NEW] Provide link to GitHub job in generated PR comment (#11)
[NEW] Report source of dependency in dependency-graph via debug logging (#44)
[FIX] Unknown command-line option '--dependency-verification' with Gradle 5.6 (#15)
[FIX] Dependency submission action should handle non-executable gradlew script (#17)
[FIX] Dependency submission fails when project isolation is enabled (#39)

body:
Bumps idna from 3.4 to 3.7.

Release notes
Sourced from idna's releases.

v3.7
What's Changed

Fix issue where specially crafted inputs to encode() could take exceptionally long amount of time to process. [CVE-2024-3651]

Thanks to Guido Vranken for reporting the issue.
Full Changelog: kjd/idna@v3.6...v3.7



Changelog
Sourced from idna's changelog.

3.7 (2024-04-11)
++++++++++++++++

Fix issue where specially crafted inputs to encode() could
take exceptionally long amount of time to process. [CVE-2024-3651]

Thanks to Guido Vranken for reporting the issue.
3.6 (2023-11-25)
++++++++++++++++

Fix regression to include tests in source distribution.

3.5 (2023-11-24)
++++++++++++++++

Update to Unicode 15.1.0
String codec name is now "idna2008" as overriding the system codec
"idna" was not working.
Fix typing error for codec encoding
"setup.cfg" has been added for this release due to some downstream
lack of adherence to PEP 517. Should be removed in a future release
so please prepare accordingly.
Removed reliance on a symlink for the "idna-data" tool to comport
with PEP 517 and the Python Packaging User Guide for sdist archives.
Added security reporting protocol for project

Thanks Jon Ribbens, Diogo Teles Sant'Anna, Wu Tingfeng for contributions
to this release.

resolves #1615
Instead of having all metadata in one long list we would like to allow users to group metadata into subsections with optional subheading.
Summary and Screenshot
Instead of modifying the structure of the metadata I add another optional header: field to the yaml file. The default value is undefined and in this case all metadata fields without a header will be grouped together in one table and shown at the start:

Otherwise metadata with the same header will be grouped and shown together under that header, e.g.:


PR Checklist


 All necessary documentation has been adapted.
 The implemented feature is covered by an appropriate test.

body:
preview URL: https://reingest.loculus.org
Summary

Simplify ingest-related values.yaml by adding a common default config
Calculate hash based on sequences and metadata and submits to loculus
Uses this hash to decide whether INSDC sequence has changed: if so, revise instead of submit, if no change, don't do anything
Run ingest as a cronjob, so we stay up to date with INSDC sequence updates

With this PR, we will no longer get duplicate sequences (on main there are currently ~70k Ebola sequences, so each sequence has been uploaded 20x, this will no longer happen)
title: feat: stateful reingest from NCBI, avoiding duplicated uploads

body: I encountered an issue where entering a bannerMessage containing a : crashed the deployments! This was because this resulted in the bannerMessage being interepreted as a helm mapping. Using quote fixes this, and is a pattern we technically should be using everywhere. This does that in a number of places, though isn't at all exhaustive. quote treats a value really as a string only.
title: Use `quote` for adding (some) Helm values

body:
resolves #1620

preview URL: https://feat-mutation-badges2.loculus.org/
Summary
This PR makes it easier to view lists of substitutions by adding a pill button around each mutation and coloring the nucleotides and aminoacids.

It modifies the metdata to have a customDisplay of type 'badge', and an optional argument of type value which is a list of mutation objects (type mutationProportionCount in lapis). The mutationProportionCount type is also modified to take further fields which correspond to the output returned by lapis (see function in lapis2/src/main/kotlin/org/genspectrum/lapis/response/LapisResponse.kt):

data class NucleotideMutationResponse(
    val mutation: String,
    val count: Int,
    val proportion: Double,
    val sequenceName: String?,
    val mutationFrom: String,
    val mutationTo: String,
    val position: Int)


It changes the lapisclient to expect processed mutation data from lapis (lapis was modified to return processed data in GenSpectrum/LAPIS#723). This is good for us as it means that the frontend will nolonger have to process a large mutation string to display mutations but can use the processed data from lapis.
It uses the NucSubBadge and an AaSubBadge component defined in #1446 to turn each mutation into a badge object.

Screenshot


PR Checklist


 Decide how to display a large number of substitutions - should we add a tab like the one added in #1631? Or should we just fill multiple lines?
 What color scheme should we use for this? Is there a loculus color scheme that would be better suited for this?
 All necessary documentation has been adapted.
 The implemented feature is covered by an appropriate test.
title: Feat(webpage): Add mutation badges to the metadata view page.

body:
This PR adds a minimal functional SARS-CoV-2 preprocessing service and a mock server to test the implementation.
It requests unaligned nucleotide sequences from /extract-unprocessed-data and submits the results of a Nextclade run to /submit-processed-data.
It takes in unaligned nucleotide sequences and returns:

Pango lineage
Aligned nucleotide sequence

It is simple to extend with further sequence derived fields that are output by Nextclade.
The code is not production quality but a first stab at implementing this feature.
Besides general refactor/cleanup, further work would involve configuration through config file, so as not be SARS-CoV-2 specific.
To dockerify the service, I suggest to use micromamba-docker: https://micromamba-docker.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quick_start.html
Overview

Download Nextclade dataset
Poll server for new sequences
Put sequences into temporary directory
Run Nextclade on sequences
Parse Nextclade results
Delete temporary directory
Submit results to server

Setup
Start directly


Install conda/mamba/micromamba


Install environment:
mamba env create -n pathoplexus-nextclade -f environment.yml


Start mock server
mamba activate pathoplexus-nextclade
python mock-server.py


Start pipeline
mamba activate pathoplexus-nextclade
python main.py
title: Nextclade Preprocessing Service

Split the loculus pod into its constituent parts. This will enable us to scale up any component that is limiting, without scaling up the others (this scaling can also be done automatically by kubernetes). It also makes the status clearer in ArgoCD.
In the process I identified various bugs in our deployment, which this also addresses. To help debug that I added a --template option to deploy.py helm which just outputs the kubernetes yamls.
title: feat(deployment): split `loculus` pods up into `backend`, `website` and `database`

body:
See docs: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codebuild/latest/userguide/action-runner.html
I tested various runner sizes. By default we use medium. E2E benefits from large runners
xlarge is only 1min faster (5.40min vs 6.40min) - probably not worth the extra 20ct
There seems to be a bug in aws codebuild (it's only been out 2 days) causing one in 10 jobs or so to stall forever (or maybe only when we send lots of parallel jobs). Another reason to only use it for a few jobs for now.
Using aws halves our E2E runtimes!
Unfortunately I couldn't get Windows dev test to work with aws.
I needed to install helm properly to get it to work with invokation of helm via ./deploy.py - otherwise everything went smoothly.
Also make backend tests retry up to 3 times to make flakiness less annoying.
title: feat(ci): Use aws codebuild self-hosted github runners for slow/expensive steps

Release notes

astro@4.7.0
Minor Changes


#10665 7b4f284 Thanks @​Princesseuh! - Adds new utilities to ease the creation of toolbar apps including defineToolbarApp to make it easier to define your toolbar app and app and server helpers for easier communication between the toolbar and the server. These new utilities abstract away some of the boilerplate code that is common in toolbar apps, and lower the barrier of entry for app authors.
For example, instead of creating an event listener for the app-toggled event and manually typing the value in the callback, you can now use the onAppToggled method. Additionally, communicating with the server does not require knowing any of the Vite APIs anymore, as a new server object is passed to the init function that contains easy to use methods for communicating with the server.
import { defineToolbarApp } from "astro/toolbar";
export default defineToolbarApp({
init(canvas, app, server) {

app.addEventListener("app-toggled", (e) => {

 console.log(`App is now ${state ? "enabled" : "disabled"}`);.


});


app.onToggled(({ state }) => {

   console.log(`App is now ${state ? "enabled" : "disabled"}`);


});


if (import.meta.hot) {

 import.meta.hot.send("my-app:my-client-event", { message: "world" });


}


server.send("my-app:my-client-event",

resolves #

preview URL:
Summary
A big refactor to how secrets are managed. They are now specified in a block in Values.yaml which looks like this:
secrets:
    type: raw
    data:
      url: "jdbc:postgresql://loculus-database-service/loculus"
      username: "postgres"
      password: "password"

A secret can have three types: raw which means the raw value provided is used as the value, sealed which means the value provided is a SealedSecret which will be unsealed on the target server on deployment and autogen which means the server will randomly generate a value for this secret (but then keep it consistent for that deployment).
Adds a special values file which is specifically for preview deployments.
Screenshot

PR Checklist


 All necessary documentation has been adapted.
 The implemented feature is covered by an appropriate test.
title: refactor(deployment): secrets overhaul

Changelog
Sourced from org.apache.commons:commons-csv's changelog.

Apache Commons CSV Version 1.11.0
Release Notes
This document contains the release notes for the 1.11.0 version of Apache Commons CSV.
Commons CSV reads and writes files in variations of the Comma Separated Value (CSV) format.
Commons CSV requires at least Java 8.
The Apache Commons CSV library provides a simple interface for reading and writing CSV files of various types.
Feature and bug fix release (Java 8 or above)
Changes in this version include:
New Features

CSV-308:  [Javadoc] Add example to CSVFormat#setHeaderComments() #344. Thanks to Buddhi De Silva, Gary Gregory.

      Add and use CSVFormat#setTrailingData(boolean) in CSVFormat.EXCEL for Excel compatibility [#303](https://github.com/apache/commons-csv/issues/303). Thanks to DamjanJovanovic, Gary Gregory.



      Add and use CSVFormat#setLenientEof(boolean) in CSVFormat.EXCEL for Excel compatibility [#303](https://github.com/apache/commons-csv/issues/303). Thanks to DamjanJovanovic, Gary Gregory.



Fixed Bugs

CSV-306:  Replace deprecated method in user guide, update external link #324, #325. Thanks to Sam Ng, Bruno P. Kinoshita.

      Document duplicate header behavior [#309](https://github.com/apache/commons-csv/issues/309). Thanks to Seth Falco, Bruno P. Kinoshita.



      Add missing docs [#328](https://github.com/apache/commons-csv/issues/328). Thanks to jkbkupczyk.



      [StepSecurity] CI: Harden GitHub Actions [#329](https://github.com/apache/commons-csv/issues/329),

Bumps the minorandpatch group in /docs with 2 updates: @astrojs/starlight and astro.
Updates @astrojs/starlight from 0.21.5 to 0.22.1

Release notes
Sourced from @​astrojs/starlight's releases.

@​astrojs/starlight@​0.22.1
Patch Changes

1c0fc384 Thanks @​HiDeoo! - Fixes an issue where the siteTitle property would not be set when using the <StarlightPage /> component.

@​astrojs/starlight@​0.22.0
Minor Changes


#640 7dc503ea Thanks @​HiDeoo! - Adds support for syncing multiple sets of tabs on the same page.


#1620 ca0678ca Thanks @​emjio! - Adds support for translating the site title
⚠️ Potentially breaking change: The shape of the title field on Starlight’s internal config object has changed. This used to be a string, but is now an object.
If you are relying on config.title (for example in a custom <SiteTitle> or <Head> component), you will need to update your code. We recommend using the new siteTitle prop available to component overrides:
---
import type { Props } from '@astrojs/starlight/props';
// The site title for this page’s language:
const { siteTitle } = Astro.props;


#1613 61493e55 Thanks @​HiDeoo! - Adds new draft frontmatter option to exclude a page from production builds.


#640 7dc503ea Thanks @​HiDeoo! - Updates the default line-height from 1.8 to 1.75. This change avoids having a line height with a fractional part which can cause scripts accessing dimensions involving the line height to get an inconsistent rounded value in various browsers.
If you want to preserve the previous line-height, you can add the following custom CSS to your site:
:root {
	--sl-line-height: 1.8;
}
