This PR adds configs for the deployment to netlify.
With netlify, we can automatically deploy the default branch and all PRs against the default branch. The default branch will be deployed to https://pathoplexus.netlify.app/. An example of the preview deployment can be seen in #32.
The deployments are password-protected. I'll share the password on Slack.
To make it work, I changed the config from YAML to JSON. Reason is that I needed to compile the test config into the bundle as we cannot provide a config file to netlify that it can access during runtime.

body:
I noticed that the website didn't shut down until timeout when sending ctrl+c to docker compose up. This fixes the issue.
When running a Node.js application inside a Docker container, the Node.js process doesn't run as PID 1, so it doesn't receive signals like SIGINT directly.
Another option is to use the tini init system directly in your Dockerfile by installing it and setting it as the entry point.
title: fix: Add `init: true` to docker-compose.yml to pass thru sigint

body:
Draft/WIP.
I'm concerned about us painting ourselves into a corner by designing a really nice navigation system that doesn't work with our plan to expand to multiple pathogens. This is an attempt to start a change to avoid that.
Limitations:

We don't have pages for multiple pathogens yet so it is implemented in a hacky way, the intent is to force us to consider design rather as we go, rather than that this is the final code (or the final design)
At time of creating the (Draft) PR I haven't changed the mobile design
It's really ugly atm. We need to think about what we actually want it to look like. This is an attempt to force us to do that.
I don't think we'll actually want a "Revise" menu item in the end - I think it would be either "Manage submissions" or something, or part of the submit area

There are no new options and no changes to how you author code blocks and syntax highlighting. Potentially breaking change: While this refactor should be transparent for most projects, the transition to shikiji now produces a smaller HTML markup by attaching a fallback color style to the pre or code element, instead of to the line span directly. For example: Before: 
    my code
After: 
    my code
This does not affect the colors as the span will inherit the color from the parent, but if you're relying on a specific HTML markup, please check your site carefully after upgrading to verify the styles. body:
Previously I was using argocd from a separate repo within pathoplexus but I've now figured out how to combine the two which should allow reconfiguration of the containers as needed. This adds a helm template for a kubernetes deployment of each pathoplexus branch for previews. It's adapted from the docker compose file.
ArgoCD is running on Theo's kubernetes cluster and watches for pathoplexus PRs with the preview tag. It then creates a preview at [branch_name].preview.pathoplexus.org with the full backend. E.g. this PR is at http://add-argocd-to-monorepo.preview.pathoplexus.org/
(Until this is merged, it won't work for other branches, because the other branches need to have this .argocd folder)

body:
Bumps msw from 1.3.2 to 2.0.0.

Release notes
Sourced from msw's releases.

v2.0.0 (2023-10-23)

[!IMPORTANT]
This release is a BREAKING CHANGE. Please follow the Migration guidelines to upgrade. This release took a lot of effort to make, and I expect a bit of that effort on your part while upgrading. Most of the changes are mechanical, and a simple Find/Replace All will get you a long way. For the rest of it, you will learn how to handle requests and responses using the standard JavaScript API. Thank you!

Breaking changes

Drops support for Node.js 16. Please upgrade to Node.js 18 or later to use the global Fetch API.
Drops support for TypeScript < 4.7.
All browser-side exports, like setupWorker, SetupWorkerApi, etc., must be imported from msw/browser now.
Renames the rest object to http (rest.get -> http.get).


Response resolver call signature is no longer (req, res, ctx) => res() but instead ({ request }) => new Response().


The following exports are removed due to no longer being needed:

response
context and related exports (defaultContext, restContext, graphqlContext).
compose and createResponseComposition


res.once() is removed in favor of the { once: boolean } option on the request handler.
Replaces the .printHandlers() method with .listHandlers().
Removes the NetworkError class in favor of the standard Response.error().
Moves request error handling from the worker thread to the client thread.
Changes the call signature of the Life-cycle Events API to accept a single object argument.
Uses crypto.randomUUID() instead of Math.random() in the worker.
For the full list of changes and detailed instructions on how to upgrade please see the Migration guidelines.

Features

Adopts Fetch API primitives. Represent intercepted requests and mocked responses as Request and Response instances respectively.
Supports Node.js v18.
Supports ReadableStream as a mocked response body.
Supports reading the intercepted request body as FormData.
Supports FormData as a mocked re

body:
As discussed, isRevocation versions are filtered out for now.
how should we handle isRevocation for the get-released-data endpoint? Should every version that are concluded ultimately with a isRevocation version flagged with isRevoked?
Current state: exclude isRevocation versions.
More details:

A sequence version with isRevocation=true is fundamentally different since we get rid of processed data, which is the current return scheme for the endpoint (data class ProcessedData)
we can fill it up with dummy data
we can wrap the whole data, so that one can differentiate later on
we can copy when creating a revocation version, so that we can here avoid additional logic
title: feat(backend): add get-released-data endpoint
feat(website): add central website page -> url mapping

astro@2.8.0
Minor Changes


#7532 9e5fafa2b Thanks @​ematipico! - The astro/middleware module exports a new utility called trySerializeLocals.
This utility can be used by adapters to validate their locals before sending it
to the Astro middleware.
This function will throw a runtime error if the value passed is not serializable, so
consumers will need to handle that error.


#7532 9e5fafa2b Thanks @​ematipico! - Astro exposes the middleware file path to the integrations in the hook astro:build:ssr
// myIntegration.js
import type { AstroIntegration } from 'astro';
function integration(): AstroIntegration {
  return {
    name: 'fancy-astro-integration',
    hooks: {
      'astro:build:ssr': ({ middlewareEntryPoint }) => {
        if (middlewareEntryPoint) {
          // do some operations
        }
      },
    },
  };
}
The middlewareEntryPoint is only defined if the user has created an Astro middleware.

body: Working branch
title: WIP: new argo

body:
This gets ArgoCD working on the new infrastructure and makes a number of changes:
Proof that it works is that this branch deploys to https://newargo2.preview.k3s.pathoplexus.org/

We now use "sealed secrets". Secrets are stored git but in a form where they can only be decrypted on our server.
This means that we can (and do) put each preview into its own namespace. That means that we can in future split things up into a large number of deployments per preview instance which will be closer to a real Kubernetes deployment and this will help to have config from Helm files.
I wasn't able to get SSL working fully through basic Ingress with cluster-issuer (I know we did previously so this is confusing). Instead I've used IngressRoute here, the traefik special option.
title: ArgoCD on new infrastructure

body:
This adds support for segmented genomes on the backend side and closes loculus-project/private_issues#2.
If the reference genome has multiple nucleotide sequences, the FASTA headers must have the suffix _<segment name>. If the reference genome has only one nucleotide sequence, the FASTA file must not have a segment name suffix (i.e., although internally, we call the sequence main, _main is not allowed).
Regarding the tests: The existing reference_genomes.json already contains two genomes, so I adapted existing tests to submit FASTA with the correct header.
As far as I can see, we don't have a setup at the moment to use different referece_genomes.json files, so we can't easily test the case of a single segment.
The k3s preview: https://multi-segments.preview.k3s.pathoplexus.org/ (It uses the reference_genomes.json of SARS-CoV-2 which only has one segment.)
title: Backend: Segmented genomes

body: This should ensure that even when images take a while to build the preview instances eventually update. It will take a while to be sure how well this is working but since it is already deployed I would like to keep the github up to date with the current status (by merging this)
title: use argocd image updater

body:
Cleans up kubernetes now that everything is in its own namespace so we don't need complicated names
Adds new helm value mode which can be set to e2e for end to end testing, and enables an ingress specific to e2e tests and a different way of getting secrets, since they can't be sealed in this context
Adds a GitHub action which runs the helm chart in k3d. At the moment it just takes a screenshot but in due course it will run the full E2E tests.

Would be keen to get this merged before implementing the full E2E piece: ticket for the full E2E playwright test in kubernetes is #456
title: Clean up Kubernetes and add (preliminary) Kubernetes E2E test
dummy-preprocessing: option to add errors and warnings to the processed data

body:
submit: reintroduced submitting via api to reduce reasons for flakyness.


review: probably caused by multiple unnecessary navigation. In separation and sequential now robust green


{ waitUntil: 'networkidle' } eleviate seemingly issues that could come from hyrdration. Playwright advises to disable interactive elements before hydration, so it doesnt interact and nothing happens.


Current Status:
For npm run start-server (the more important case):
e2e run much more robust. Didnt see any failures for 10+ runs. Rarely, there is one of 36 tests flaky, i.e., there is a retry that succeeded.
For npm run dev:
e2e can fail and are not as robust as in the previous case


reworked some of the tests:



reduced number by merging tests that can easily be merged into one.
reduced usage of verifyTableEntries by collecting sequences that needs verification as this function is very slow
e2e tests w/o retries run now significantly faster. Serial on ci now ~ 1 min 30 sec (local with parallelism ~ 25 sec)

body:
Bumps msw from 1.3.2 to 2.0.1.

Release notes
Sourced from msw's releases.

v2.0.1 (2023-10-28)
Bug Fixes

clone response early for response logging (#1799) (5c5470a0f2204b4164fcc65e210471661208ce4d) @​kunmagg

v2.0.0 (2023-10-23)

[!IMPORTANT]
This release is a BREAKING CHANGE. Please follow the Migration guidelines to upgrade. This release took a lot of effort to make, and I expect a bit of that effort on your part while upgrading. Most of the changes are mechanical, and a simple Find/Replace All will get you a long way. For the rest of it, you will learn how to handle requests and responses using the standard JavaScript API. Thank you!

Breaking changes

Drops support for Node.js 16. Please upgrade to Node.js 18 or later to use the global Fetch API.
Drops support for TypeScript < 4.7.
All browser-side exports, like setupWorker, SetupWorkerApi, etc., must be imported from msw/browser now.
Renames the rest object to http (rest.get -> http.get).


Response resolver call signature is no longer (req, res, ctx) => res() but instead ({ request }) => new Response().


The following exports are removed due to no longer being needed:

response
context and related exports (defaultContext, restContext, graphqlContext).
compose and createResponseComposition


res.once() is removed in favor of the { once: boolean } option on the request handler.
Replaces the .printHandlers() method with .listHandlers().
Removes the NetworkError class in favor of the standard Response.error().
Moves request error handling from the worker thread to the client thread.
Changes the call signature of the Life-cycle Events API to accept a single object argument.
Uses crypto.randomUUID() instead of Math.random() in the worker.
For the full list of changes and detailed instructions on how to upgrade please see the Migration guidelines.

Features

Adopts Fetch API primitives. Represent intercepted requests and mocked responses as Request and Response instances respectively.
Supports Node.js v18.
Support

Bumps msw from 1.3.2 to 2.0.3.

Release notes
Sourced from msw's releases.

v2.0.3 (2023-11-04)
Bug Fixes

correctly check "undefined" as response body type (#1824) (a0ec8be311daef0285d8485e315bbb49a9370f44) @​kettanaito
Safari: send explicit null response bodies (#1833) (66fb437c0936651cf0bb936f21aa77054b147857) @​kettanaito

v2.0.2 (2023-11-01)
Bug Fixes

output a single formatted message to console (#1820) (2ead3922f3ec5a4750e3b9e09e75aeb20f13c736) @​kettanaito
prevent one-time handlers from incorrectly marking themselves as used (#1822) (a179b68e2dfd3667999c31b1dbd3870a0b92568c) @​joshkel
resolve the "eventTargets" error in JSDOM by dropping "instanceof"  (#1813) (f6e5112fa0f1ebbd97fb95bcbda1c47a0cc750f9) @​mattcosta7

v2.0.1 (2023-10-28)
Bug Fixes

clone response early for response logging (#1799) (5c5470a0f2204b4164fcc65e210471661208ce4d) @​kunmagg

v2.0.0 (2023-10-23)

[!IMPORTANT]
This release is a BREAKING CHANGE. Please follow the Migration guidelines to upgrade. This release took a lot of effort to make, and I expect a bit of that effort on your part while upgrading. Most of the changes are mechanical, and a simple Find/Replace All will get you a long way. For the rest of it, you will learn how to handle requests and responses using the standard JavaScript API. Thank you!

Breaking changes

Drops support for Node.js 16. Please upgrade to Node.js 18 or later to use the global Fetch API.
Drops support for TypeScript < 4.7.
All browser-side exports, like setupWorker, SetupWorkerApi, etc., must be imported from msw/browser now.
Renames the rest object to http (rest.get -> http.get).


Response resolver call signature is no longer (req, res, ctx) => res() but instead ({ request }) => new Response().


The following exports are removed due to no longer being needed:

response
context and related exports (defaultContext, restContext, graphqlContext).
compose and createResponseComposition


res.once() is removed in favor of the { once: boolean } option on the req

body:
Bumps daisyui from 3.9.4 to 4.0.3.

Release notes
Sourced from daisyui's releases.

daisyUI 4.0
Breaking changes

🌈 OKLCH colors

daisyUI 4 uses wide-gamut OKLCH colors internally instead of HSL now.
The new OKLCH color model unlock access to 30% more colors comparing to RGB/HSL.
All internal color variables (--p, --s, etc) now contain OKLCH values instead of HSL.
If you're using those CSS variables directly inside your project like hsl(var(--p)) you have to change it to oklch(var(--p))
OKLCH colors are supported in Chrome/Edge 111+, Safari 15.4+, Firefox 113+
For old browsers, daisyUI provides HEX fallback colors only for the default dark/light themes.
Read more about OKLCH colors here.


🌈 Color names

Removed all *-focus color names. They where being used only for buttons.
Darker colors are now generated using CSS color-mix() under the hood.
The following class names are removed now:

primary-focus
secondary-focus
accent-focus
neutral-focus


You can also make a color darker or lighter using CSS color-mix(). For example to make primary (--p) color darker, you can use this class name:
bg-[color-mix(in_oklab,oklch(var(--p)),black)]


🎨 Themes

All theme colors adjusted for better contrast, better color harmony and better accessibility.


🧠 Logical CSS properties

daisyUI 4 components use logical CSS properties instead of directional rules (mr-*, pl-*, etc)
If you are using directional CSS rules (right/left) to modify daisyUI styles, it still works fine in LTR mode but you may want to double check.


⬅️ RTL

Removed rtl daisyUI config
All components now support LTR/RTL without any config or plugin.
You don't need tailwindcss-flip plugin anymore.
You don't need to set rtl: true in tailwind.config.js
Just add dir=rtl to <html> tag and everything will be RTL on runtime.


🗂️ Tab

No need to repeat modifier classes for each tab item.
these modifier classes for tab are removed:

tab-lifted
tab-bordered
tab-lg
tab-md
tab-sm
tab-xs


Use the following modifier classes for

body:
I added some very basic stuff to the README explaining, what to do to start the server and how to conduct tests.
What else should be there?
title: feat(website): add basic instructions to use this repo

body: This removes the namespace annotation from the IngressClass as my understanding is that IngressClass is inherently cluster-wide and not namespaceable, so this reflects the reality. We should consider whether we should incorporate the branch name into the ingress class name so that we get one class per instance. TBH I don't understand the classes enough to know if we need to do that.
title: Remove namespace from ingress class as it is unused

body:
Remove "ingress-for-testing" which has actually been unused for a long time (my fault)
Remove any references to ingress-nginx: preview deployments were getting confused by having multiple ingress servers running at once [specifically, we were getting multiple ingress-nginx'es all trying to use the same port on the node]
Rewrite the lapis ingress to use Traefik ingress routes (using ChatGPT)
Edit: combine the lapis ingresses for e2e and cd together

We should at some stage consider supporting multiple ingress servers (i.e. not just Traefik, to support roll-outs in different environments but we should probably do this holistically, rather than mixing the two as we were)
title: Amend ingress approach to remove nginx

Updates org.postgresql:postgresql from 42.6.0 to 42.7.0

Release notes
Sourced from org.postgresql:postgresql's releases.

v42.7.0
Known issues

NoSuchMethodError on ByteBuffer#position When Running on Java 8  when accessing arrays, issue pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3014
SET followed by SHOW in one statement returns wrong result, issue pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3007
42.7.0 updated DateStyle from ISO to ISO, MDY (it aligns with PostgreSQL defaults), and it result in wrong results when server uses non-default DateStyle (see pgjdbc/pgjdbc#3008)

Changes

update website for 42.7.0 @​davecramer (#3003)
Update changelog for release 42.7.0 @​davecramer (#3001)
Use a switch statement to compare transaction isolation levels and let the database do the toUpper @​davecramer (#2998)
feat: support SET statements combining with other queries with semicolon in PreparedStatement @​ng-galien (#2973)
Return correct default from PgDatabaseMetaData.getDefaultTransactionIsolation @​nvanbenschoten (#2992)
only create function if V14 or greater @​davecramer (#2996)
Fix problem when calling a procedure returning a refcursor more than 5 times (prepareThreshold)  @​davecramer (#2988)
chore: add styleCheck Gradle task to report style violations @​vlsi (#2980)
Include currentXid in exception message @​gastaldi (#2978)
Deprecate for removal PGPoint.setLocation(java.awt.Point) to cut dependency to java.desktop module @​desruisseaux (#2967)
feat: return all catalogs for getCatalogs metadata query (#2949) @​pip25 (#2953)
fix: add varbit as a basic type inside the TypeInfoCache @​fqazi (#2960)
Fix failing tests for version 16.  @​davecramer (#2962)
fix: allow setting arrays with ANSI type name @​bremac (#2952)
added ADOPTERS.md

body:
Bumps actions/setup-java from 3 to 4.

Release notes
Sourced from actions/setup-java's releases.

v4.0.0
What's Changed
In the scope of this release, the version of the Node.js runtime was updated to 20. The majority of dependencies were updated to the latest versions. From now on, the code for the setup-java will run on Node.js 20 instead of Node.js 16.
Breaking changes

Update Node.js runtime to version 20 by @​aparnajyothi-y in actions/setup-java#558

Non-breaking changes

Adding support for microsoft openjdk 21.0.0 by @​ralfstuckert in actions/setup-java#546
Update @​actions/cache dependency and documentation by @​IvanZosimov in actions/setup-java#549
Implementation of the cache-dependency-path option to control caching dependency by @​itchyny in actions/setup-java#499

New Contributors

@​ralfstuckert made their first contribution in actions/setup-java#546
@​itchyny made their first contribution in actions/setup-java#499

Full Changelog: actions/setup-java@v3...v4.0.0
v3.13.0
What's changed
In the scope of this release, support for Dragonwell JDK was added by @​Accelerator1996 in actions/setup-java#532
steps:
 - name: Checkout
   uses: actions/checkout@v3
 - name: Setup-java
   uses: actions/setup-java@v3
   with:
     distribution: 'dragonwell'
     java-version: '17'
Several inaccuracies were also fixed:

Fix XML namespaces wrongly using https by @​gnodet in actions/setup-java#503
Fix typo and remove unintentional(?) word by @​CyberFlameGO in actions/setup-java#518
Fix usage link within the README.md file by @​dassiorleando in actions/setup-java#525

@​Accelerator1996 made their first contribution in actions/setup-java#532

Sourced from vitest's releases.

v1.0.1
   🐞 Bug Fixes

Bump vitest packages peerDependencies versions  -  by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#4654 (42070)

    View changes on GitHub
v1.0.0
Vitest 1.0 is here! This release page lists all changes made to the project during the beta. For the migration guide, please refer to the documentation.
   🚨 Breaking Changes

Add support for pool and poolOptions, remove old flags  -  by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#4172 (114a9)
Support multiple parallel child_process  -  by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#3925 (8b4a4)

Bump minimum node version to 18 and match Vite 5 requirement  -  by @​ghiscoding in vitest-dev/vitest#4296 (263b7)
Remove deprecated node loader  -  by @​sheremet-va in vitest-dev/vitest#4371 (29299)
Move browser providers to @​vitest/browser package  -  by @​sheremet-va in vitest-dev/vitest#4364 (5cdeb)
Remove EnhancedSpy type, deprecate SpyInstance, improve mocks and vi documentation  -  by @​sheremet-va and @​dammy001 in vitest-dev/vitest#4400 (d40b3)
runner: Correctly process custom tasks, update runner hooks naming by @​sheremet-va in vitest-dev/vitest#4076
coverage:

glob based coverage thresholds by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#4442 (18300)
Use transformMode and workspace project based source maps  -  by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#4309 (28109cc)
Enable coverage.all by default  -  by @​AriPerkkio in vitest-dev/vitest#4265 (5a741)



   🚀 Features

Add Marko example and include code coverage for Marko files  -  by @​DylanPiercey in vitest-dev/vitest#4263 (eac77)
Update magic-string  -  by @​bluwy in vitest-dev/vitest#4345 (fde18)
Implement provide/inject API to transfer data from the main thread  -  by @​sheremet-va in vitest-dev/vitest#4422 (a7522)

body: When you enter a helm loop the contents of .Values changes so it no longer has the root values. We've previously been dealing with this by assigning the variables we needed outside of the loop, but its a bit verbose. I finally asked ChatGPT and it told me about $.Values where the $ is the root context. Let's use that?

Cleanup java sources #38877

HibernateJpaAutoConfiguration should be applied before DataSourceTransactionManagerAutoConfiguration #38880
META-INF entries are duplicated under BOOT-INF/classes causing "Conflicting persistence unit definitions" error #38862

Custom binding converters are ignored when working with collection types #38734
WebFlux and resource server auto-configuration may fail due to null authentication manager #38713

Spring Boot jar launcher does not work in folders containing certain chars #38660
FileNotFoundException is thrown eagerly from unused SSL bundles #38659
NoUniqueBeanDefinitionFailureAnalyzer does not account for the fact that missing '-parameters' may be the cause #38652

body:
Changes logic to have a specified list of routes for which login should be forced. Naming change from isPrivate to shouldMiddlewareForceLogin is intentional, because you can also have a private route that maintains privacy in its own way e.g. by saying "Please login to use this feature" if the user is not logged in. (In future we may want to remove some middleware login in favour of that).
Fixes #729

body:
So I hadn't properly realised until now that we weren't providing an actual way to customise the configuration (viruses, genomes, etc.) without editing the helm chart itself. Let's provide that :)
This changes things so that this is included in the Helm values file. That means that when doing a helm deployment you can simply provide a different values file - e.g. we can have one set of values for the test with short genomes, and one for the real organism instance that @corneliusroemer is working on.
To use with a different values file you just run:
helm install loculus kubernetes/loculus -f my-values.yaml
title: Include instance configurations in Helm values

body:
This PR aims to improve the search form on mobile devices by moving it to an off-canvas. It also takes up the idea in #82 and made the search button (on desktop and on mobile) sticky and always visible.

Code-wise, I extracted some code from the off-canvas navigation and created a useOffCanvas hook, an OffCanvasOverlay component, and a CSS class offCanvasTransform. Happy to receive feedback on whether this is a good way to reuse the code. I thought about creating a reusable OffCanvas component but didn't really know how.
I didn't write any test for this PR. Regarding e2e tests, I suggest that we first wait for #63. We could test the useOffCanvas hook but as it is really simple, I'm not sure whether it is worth setting up something like react-hooks-testing-library (which itself recommends that simple hooks that are closely tied to a component should be simply tested with the components).
title: feat(website): move search form on mobile to an offcanvas

@​astrojs/starlight@​0.16.0
Minor Changes


#1383 490c6ef Thanks @​delucis! - Refactors Starlight’s internal virtual module system for components to avoid circular references
This is a change to an internal API.
If you were importing the internal virtual:starlight/components module, this no longer exists.
Update your imports to use the individual virtual modules now available for each component, for example virtual:starlight/components/EditLink.


#1151 134292d Thanks @​kevinzunigacuellar! - Fixes sidebar auto-generation issue when a file and a directory, located at the same level, have identical names.
For example, src/content/docs/guides.md and src/content/docs/guides/example.md will now both be included and src/content/docs/guides.md is treated in the same way a src/content/docs/guides/index.md file would be.


#1386 0163634 Thanks @​delucis! - Tightens line-height on <LinkCard> titles to fix regression from original design
If you want to preserve the previous line-height, you can add the following custom CSS to your site:
.sl-link-card a {
	line-height: 1.6;
}


#1376 8398432 Thanks @​delucis! - Tweaks vertical spacing in Markdown content styles.
This is a subtle change to Starlight’s default content styling that should improve most sites:

Default vertical spacing between content items is reduced from 1.5rem to 1rem.
Spacing before headings is now relative to font size, meaning higher-level headings have slightly more spacing and lower-level headings slightly less.

The overall impact is to tighten up content that belongs together and improve the visual hierarchy of headings to break up sections.
Although this is a subtle change, we recommend visually inspecting your site in case this impacts layout of any custom CSS or components.
If you want to preserve the previous spacing, you

Updates io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api from 0.12.3 to 0.12.4

Release notes
Sourced from io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api's releases.

0.12.4
This is patch release completes 10 issues, with two especially noteworthy changes, and a number of other smaller bug fixes and enhancements.

The default Jackson deserializer will now reject duplicate JSON members by default in an attempt to be a little more strict at rejecting potentially malicious or malformed JSON.  This is a default and can be overridden with a custom ObjectMapper if desired.
Password-based JWE encryption key algorithms (PBES2_HS256_A128KW, PBES2_HS384_A192KW and PBES2_HS512_A256KW) now enforce an upper bound (maximum) number of iterations allowed during decryption to mitigate against potential DoS attacks. Many thanks to Jingcheng Yang and Jianjun Chen from Sichuan University and Zhongguancun Lab for their work on this!

A number of other issues fixed: thread-safe ServiceLoader usage for dynamic JSON processor lookup, Android enhancements for JSON Reader APIs, fixed Elliptic Curve field element padding, and more.  Please read the 0.12.4 CHANGELOG for full details of all of these changes, and as always, project documentation is in the 0.12.4 README.
Please allow 30 minutes from the time this announcement is published for the release to be available in Maven Central.



Changelog
Sourced from io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api's changelog.

0.12.4
This patch release includes various changes listed below.
Jackson Default Parsing Behavior
This release makes two behavioral changes to JJWT's default Jackson ObjectMapper parsing settings:


In the interest of having stronger standards to reject potentially malformed/malicious/accidental JSON that could
have undesirable effects on an application, JJWT's default ObjectMapper is now configured to explicitly reject/fa

Release notes
Sourced from gradle/gradle-build-action's releases.

v3.0.0-rc.2
Release candidate for gradle/gradle-build-action@v3.0.0.
This release candidate will be available under the v3 version tag.

[!IMPORTANT]
As of v3 this action has been superceded by gradle/actions/setup-gradle.
Any workflow that uses gradle/gradle-build-action@v3 will transparently delegate to gradle/actions/setup-gradle@v3.
Users are encouraged to update their workflows, replacing:
uses: gradle/gradle-build-action@v3

with
uses: gradle/actions/setup-gradle@v3

See the setup-gradle documentation for up-to-date documentation for gradle/actons/setup-gradle.

Changes from gradle-build-action@v2
This release brings some useful and much requested features, including:

save and restore the Gradle configuration-cache data
add the Job summary content as a PR comment
easily publish Build Scans® to the free Gradle Build Scan service
compatibility with Node 20

The only major breaking change from gradle-build-action@v2.12.0 is the update to require a Node 20 runtime environment.
Aside from that change, this release should generally serve as a drop-in replacement for gradle-build-action@v2.
Changelog

[NEW] - Run with NodeJs 20.x (gradle/gradle-build-action#946)
[NEW] - Support for save & restore of configuration-cache data (gradle/gradle-build-action#966)
[NEW] - Support for automatic adding PR comment with Job Summary content (gradle/gradle-build-action#1020)
[NEW] - Make it easy to publish a Build Scan® to https://scans.gradle.com (gradle/gradle-build-action#1044)
[NEW] - Added dependency-graph-continue-on-failure input, which can be set to false to force the Job to fail when dependency graph submission fails (gradle/gradle-build-action#1036). Failure modes include:

Fail build step if version of Gradle being executed is not supported for dependency-graph generation (gradle/gradle-build-action#1034)
Fail job if permissions are insufficient to submit d

astro@2.9.0
Minor Changes


#7686 ec745d689 Thanks @​matthewp! - Redirects configuration
This change moves the redirects configuration out of experimental. If you were previously using experimental redirects, remove the following experimental flag:
experimental: {
  redirects: true,
}
If you have been waiting for stabilization before using redirects, now you can do so. Check out the docs on redirects to learn how to use this built-in feature.


#7707 3a6e42e19 Thanks @​ottomated! - Improved hoisted script bundling
Astro's static analysis to determine which <script> tags to bundle together just got a little smarter!
Astro create bundles that optimize script usage between pages and place them in the head of the document so that they are downloaded as early as possible. One limitation to Astro's existing approach has been that you could not dynamically use hoisted scripts. Each page received the same, all-inclusive bundle whether or not every script was needed on that page.
Now, Astro has improved the static analysis to take into account the actual imports used.
For exam

body:
This creates a codespace configuration. I think you should be able to use it by creating a codespace on this branch (fyi I think our codespaces are atm billed to individual users, where billing becomes relevant). As explained by the welcome text the procedure is:

start codespace
wait for the startup script to finish (few minutes)
open a terminal and run loculusBackend
open another terminal and run loculusWebsite
finally, once the backend is running, run loculusPort to ensure it is exposed "publicly" which is needed for CORS to work correctly

Closes #881 too. Closes #892.
We now also write the runtime_config using the generate config script. The generate config script has been made part of deploy.py.
Remaining issue:
requests to the backend are blocked by CORS

body:
This PR replaces one of our two "dummy test organisms" with a real one: mpox virus. It allows us to test on more realistic genomes and configurations.
Mpox uses the real nextclade preprocessing pipeline as opposed to the dummy one used by the current test organisms.
Here is some test data (metadata and sequences) to play with:
mpox-sample-files.tar.gz
A working preview is running at: https://add-mpox-to-main.preview.k3s.loculus.org/mpox/search
Review instructions
There'll be a lot of churn in the preprocessing code and I take full responsibility there so no need to review that part closely.
However, it'd be good if you guys could check the helm stuff as this is my first time working on that part of the code base.
These are the diffs warranting closer review:

Updates io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api from 0.12.4 to 0.12.5

Release notes
Sourced from io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api's releases.

0.12.5
This release fixes issue #916 and ensures that builders' NestedCollection changes are applied to the collection immediately as mutation methods are called, no longer requiring application developers to call .and() to 'commit' or apply a change.  For example, prior to this release, the following code did not apply changes:
JwtBuilder builder = Jwts.builder();
builder.audience().add("an-audience"); // no .and() call
builder.compact(); // would not keep 'an-audience'
Now this code works as expected and all other NestedCollection instances like it apply changes immediately (e.g. when calling
.add(value)).
However, standard fluent builder chains are still recommended for readability when feasible, e.g.
Jwts.builder()
    .audience().add("an-audience").and() // allows fluent chaining
    .subject("Joe")
    // etc...
    .compact()
These same notes are repeated in the CHANGELOG, and as always, project documentation is in the README.
Please allow 30 minutes from the time this announcement is published for the release to be available in Maven Central.



Changelog
Sourced from io.jsonwebtoken:jjwt-api's changelog.

0.12.5
This patch release:


Ensures that builders' NestedCollection changes are applied to the collection immediately as mutation methods are called, no longer

builder.audience().add("an-audience"); // no .and() call
builder.compact(); // would not keep 'an-audience'
Now this code works as expected and all other NestedCollection instances like it apply changes

body:
We've been having problems with running out of certificates. This addresses that by using a single wildcard certificate for *.loculus.org. These wildcard certificates only allow one position to be a wildcard so we have converted domains to have forms like authentication-[branch].loculus.org for keycloak, rather than subdomains. Until this is merged into your branch none of your previews will work, sorry.
A good bit of this change is we now use Ingress which is the kubernetes default - rather than IngressRoute which applies only to Traefik. This should make it easier to deploy this on a range of systems.
title: single level domains

body:
Resolves #432
Our current approach to confirmation dialogs requires us to handle lots of state about what the actual action to be performed on confirmation is. We should avoid that. This PR achieves that with use-confirmation-alert. If we don't implement this now we will add even more confirmation dialogs with state, so I want to get it in. I don't have enough bandwidth or understanding of the code to re-work all the existing dialogs to use this approach, so I have renamed the old confirmation dialog to DeprecatedConfirmationDialog.tsx and have created an issue for the subsequent removal of these (#924).. I have demoed the feature on the dialog for leaving groups

resolves #948
https://try-remove-fasta-need.loculus.org/
There are tons of different extensions used for fasta files, .fasta, .fa, .seq, .fas (and more). I don't think we should demand any particular extensions. (Happy to discuss that though!) Atm we are providing downloads as .fa and demanding upload of .fasta which definitely needs fixing!
I also improve the error messages which used to say:
Failed to submit sequence entries: Sequence file has wrong extension. Must be .[fasta] for uncompressed submissions or .{NONE=[fasta], ZSTD=[fasta.zst], XZ=[fasta.xz], GZIP=[fasta.gz], ZIP=[fasta.zip], BZIP2=[fasta.bz2], LZMA=[fasta.lzma]} for compressed submissions

and now just list the extensions.

 All necessary documentation has been adapted.

body:
Resolves #743, resolves #745, resolves #546
Preview: https://keycloakify.loculus.org/


We build a custom keycloak theme with keycloakify (which is react based), which gets packaged (like most Keycloak themes) into a .jar file. We then put that jar file into a Docker image which serves just as a directory to store the image, and copies it out into a volume that is also mounted on keycloak in the right place for keycloak to get the theme. Keycloak does indeed gets the theme and uses it as the login theme.
We also enable the declarative_user_profile  feature of Keycloak, and use it to capture the user's University / Organisation.
We also add ORCid keycloak integration and capture the ORCid where possible
Outstanding issues:
#974 - put in real terms of use
#973 - this is branched from a starter template. there is more we can clean up but I don't feel ready to yet, because these are useful docs about how to e.g. add new pages, for now
#1172 - clean up ORCid secrets
title: feat(keycloak): Add keycloak theme, capture university, add ORCid integration

This PR configures the dummy preprocessing pipeline to emit errors and warnings when deployed on the server.
E2E is not touched to simplify testing. But the ability to have submissions with errors/warnings is essential to demonstrate/test how our frontend handles them.
For example, I noticed that the new submission review page shows the "release" paperplane icon even for sequences with errors. This wasn't easy to test before the code changes here.
I also add a --dry-run feature to ./deploy.py to make it easiert to see what commands it executes. This helped me understand the precise configuration used by E2E testing.

body:
Fixing the cleanup-cache action.
Background
Unfortunately the script as shown in Github docs doesn't work
https://github.com/loculus-project/loculus/actions/runs/7873524962/job/21481061540
gh extension install actions/gh-actions-cache
  
  echo "Fetching list of cache key"
  cacheKeysForPR=$(gh actions-cache list -R $REPO -B $BRANCH -L 100 | cut -f 1 )
  
  ## Setting this to not fail the workflow while deleting cache keys.
  set +e
  echo "Deleting caches..."
  for cacheKey in $cacheKeysForPR
  do
      gh actions-cache delete $cacheKey -R $REPO -B $BRANCH --confirm
  done
  echo "Done"
  shell: /usr/bin/bash -e {0}
  env:
    GH_TOKEN: ***
    REPO: loculus-project/loculus
    BRANCH: refs/pull/98[4](https://github.com/loculus-project/loculus/actions/runs/7873524962/job/21481061540#step:2:4)/merge
Fetching list of cache key
Error: Resource not accessible by integration
Deleting caches...
Done

Testing
Can be tested with:
gh workflow run --ref corneliusroemer-patch-1
title: Fix cache cleanup script (now tested to work)

body:
This bug was live between Tuesday, the 27th of August, at 18.00, until Thursday, the 29th, at 18.10. We have decided to create an issue now for visibility and tracking purposes.
Issue
On Thursday, 29th August, we identified and fixed a bug in a Loculus dependency, SILO (see loculus-project/loculus#2666). The bug meant that bulk downloads of unaligned nucleotide sequences from Pathoplexus were incorrect. The fix was rolled out to Pathoplexus in #60.
Severity:
This issue affected the endpoint for the download of bulk raw nucleotide sequences. It did not affect the sequences displayed on individual pages, the download of metadata or the download of bulk aligned sequences.
Impact:
The estimated impact is low. Analytics show a small proportion of users accessed the Browse pages (which were not themselves impacted). Of users who access the Browse pages, a very small proportion make a download. If users were making downloads, we believe that they were likely doing so to test out the website functionality and that . The error was such that it would be clearly apparent in any analyses that were made. The bug was detected internally within the SILO team rather than being reported by users.
Details of the SILO bug can be found here: GenSpectrum/LAPIS-SILO#549
title: [BUG] Retrospective Issue for Unaligned Sequence Download Bug

body:
Describe the bug
I'm not sure if this is a real bug, but I was a little confused, that navigating to the LAPIS instance without a slash gives a 404 while with a slash it is a valid url and returns the expected page. I thought I had the wrong URL.
To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Go to https://lapis.pathoplexus.org/west-nile
Then I get a 404
Go to https://lapis.pathoplexus.org/west-nile/ (with a slash) and I get the expected "welcome" page

Expected behavior
Using the link to https://lapis.pathoplexus.org/west-nile would directly show me the welcome page
Desktop (please complete the following information):

OS: Ubuntu 22.04
Browser firefox
Version 130.0.1
title: [BUG] Lapis Instance URLs without trailing slash returns 404

body:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Currently, the documentation for metadata fields is manually completely duplicated and not organism-specific, this was fine for getting things out quickly, but is not good for maintainability and the long run, especially if there will be more pathogens.
The docs duplication lives here:
https://github.com/pathoplexus/pathoplexus/blob/e1aafa93f89a0541daccdd6b67990af8c1aea7b9/monorepo/website/src/pages/docs/concepts/metadataformat.mdx?plain=1#L25-L218
And it duplicates what's in values.yaml:

  
    
      pathoplexus/loculus_values/values.yaml
    
    
        Lines 73 to 1095
      in
      e1aafa9
    
  
  
    

        
          
               metadata: 
        

        
          
                 - name: sampleCollectionDate 
        

        
          
                   displayName: Collection date 
        

        
          
                   type: date 
        

        
          
                   initiallyVisible: true 
        

        
          
                   header: Sample details 
        

        
          
                   ingest: ncbiCollectionDate 
        

        
          
                   preprocessing: 
        

        
          
                     function: parse_and_assert_past_date 
        

        
          
                     inputs: 
        

        
          
                       date: sampleCollectionDate 
        

        
          
                   required: true 
        

        
          
                 - name: displayName 
        

        
          
                   preprocessing: 
        

        
          
                     function: concatenate 
        

        
          
                     inputs: 
        

        
          
                       geoLocCountry: geoLocCountry 
        

        
          
                       sampleCollectionDate: sampleCollectionDate
title: [FEAT] Generate parts of metadataformat.mdx from values.yaml to reduce duplication

body:
Right now, the way we have things set up, shutting down a node will probably always cause downtime of the things running on it, including for production loads (if there are no replicas on at least one other node).
We sometimes might need extra nodes for previews, right now I don't feel like adding a temporary extra node because I'm worried a production load will get scheduled on there and I wouldn't want to cause production downtime due to this.
We could potentially add a taint/label to such temporary nodes that ensures that production workloads don't end up on these temporary nodes.
The best general solution would be to ensure that we can always take out any single node without causing production downtime, but we might not be there right now and it may or may not be difficult.
title: Infra: add node label to only schedule non-production workloads to allow downscaling without prod downtime

body:
As more people start using Pathoplexus data to power websites, pipelines, web-portals, etc, we should make it easier for other users to find these tools.
We could add a page or UI feature to the website that could be used to list known tools that use Pathoplexus. This could include tools that use Pathoplexus data (ex: Nextstrain builds) but also tools that help people use Pathoplexus (other tools that can submit to Pathoplexus).
This could start out basic like a list of links, but could in future be made fancier, ex, divided by pathogen and with a search bar (and/or other ideas).
There should be an email address (and github edit link if it's a simple page) so people can easily request the addition of their own tool
We should come up with some guidelines about what we'd want to advertise. For example, do we just want to link to 'live' things (if so, what does this mean?), or are we open to people also linking to static analysis results/papers? Do we want to link to code that doesn't use Pathoplexus directly but enables its use, either on front or backend?
title: [FEAT] Add a page to surface tools that use Pathoplexus

body:
While Pathoplexus is currently not focused on providing full analyses, we could help users get an overview of the data they are looking at via some simple graphs/widgets.
For example, on the search/browse page, we could have a small selection of graphs (disable-able, or perhaps selecting which ones you want to view) at the top, which change based on what search is currently showing. (Only Country Y if you've searched for Country Y - we need to make a clear decision on how that would not or would be impacted by checkboxes.)
This may include for example, breakdown by country, breakdown by lineages, number of sequences in the past X days (could auto-switch from showing country to geo_loc_1 or whatever if you filter to country?) -- and many more ideas!
title: [FEAT] Add small graphics to help users get an overview of the data

body:
Crossref says it has planned downtime - but only some services are affected. Todo:

 Figure out whether this will mean seqset creation is down: yes it will be down
 Add planned downtime notification for status.pathplexus.org
 Potentially disable seqset creation while it's down (possibly add this to Loculus as a feature)
 Potentially test what happens in a preview when crossref is down so we don't take down backend if we get errors etc

This has the latest details (hopefully): https://status.crossref.org/incidents/v3k2t9f3jdcw
Full email we got:

As you know, we are working to move our main database to a new and open system. We will be completing the final steps of this work between Monday 16th September 21:00 UTC and Tuesday 17th September 21:00 UTC.
During this time, there will be complete downtime and outage on the following Crossref services:

Deposits, including helper tools like the Web Deposit Form
Queries
Admin tool (doi.crossref.org)
Reports
OAI-PMH
OpenURL
Content negotiation

If you attempt to access these services, including making a metadata deposit, you’ll receive a 500 unavailable error message, and you will need to retry when these services are back online. We will not store or queue attempted metadata deposits or updates made during the downtime.
Crossref DOIs will continue to resolve during this time. The REST API is not affected by this work and will remain available as normal.
We initiated the migration between 20 and 21 August, 2024 and made significant progress; we are now ready to complete the proces. We realise additional scheduled downtime may cause further disruption for you, but this is critical work to move forward to a more robust, reliable, and modern infrastructure. Thank you for your support.
We’ll be keeping this maintenance alert on our status page up to date as the time approaches, but we wanted to give you as much advance notice as possible. You can subscribe to updates from that link.
title: [deadline: 14th September] Figure out whether crossref will be down for submissions for pathoplexus

body:
Bumps webfactory/ssh-agent from 0.5.3 to 0.9.0.

Release notes
Sourced from webfactory/ssh-agent's releases.

Update to node20
This release updates the action to run on Node.js v20. When you're running on GitHub hosted runners, just go ahead and update. When you're using self-hosted runners, please make sure you have Node.js v20 installed before updating from v0.8.0 to v0.9.0 of this action.
New Contributors

@​npwolf made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#196
@​benzado made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#206
@​felix-seifert made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#199
@​archen made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#201

Full Changelog: webfactory/ssh-agent@v0.8.0...v0.9.0
What's Changed

Update README.md to reflect latest version by @​npwolf in webfactory/ssh-agent#196
Remove outdated claim from README by @​benzado in webfactory/ssh-agent#206
chore: update all versions of actions/checkout to v4 by @​felix-seifert in webfactory/ssh-agent#199
bump to node20 by @​archen in webfactory/ssh-agent#201

New Contributors

@​npwolf made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#196
@​benzado made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#206
@​felix-seifert made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#199
@​archen made their first contribution in webfactory/ssh-agent#201

Full Changelog: webfactory/ssh-agent@v0.8.0...v0.9.0
SSH host keys no longer managed – read below 👇
Starting with this release, this action no longer writes GitHub's SSH host keys into the known_hosts SSH config file upon start.
GitHub changed their host keys on short notice this morning, see https://github.blog/2023-03-23-we-updated-our-rsa-ssh-host-key/. We took this as an opportunity to stop maintaining GH SSH keys in the code shipped with this action (#171).
What you need to do:

On GitHub hosted runners, nothing. ✔︎ These runners ship with SSH host keys (for github.com) maintained by directly by GitHub.
On self-hosted r
title: Bump webfactory/ssh-agent from 0.5.3 to 0.9.0

body:
Trevor Bedford identified on slack (slack link) that the current search and query via API docs don't seem to work - the given URLs are like:
https://lapis-pathoplexus.org/ebola-zaire/sample/aggregated?geoLocCountry=Uganda

I wrote these docs prior to launch so this is 100% on me - I tried to infer what our 'launch URL' would be, though I was doing the testing with our 'pre-launch-demo' URL. I forgot to check it actually turned out how I thought after launch!
It seems like the right URL uses . instead of - -- so, lapis.pathoplexus.org instead of the above.
Thus replacing all the lapis-pathoplexus.org with lapis.pathoplexus.org should fix this... I think?
Appreciate if someone else can confirm this seems to be right!
https://preview-fix-api-docs.ppx.bio
title: Replace lapis-pathoplexus with lapis.pathoplexus in query API examples

body:
This Snakemake workflow is the first step towards a Pathoplexus integrity test suite. It compares the invariant parts (i.e. not PP accessions, submit times etc) of LAPIS bulk download files across arbitrary pathoplexus deployments.
For example, it detects differences in sequences between production and old-state, and finds no differences between staging and production.
See README for full description.
Future work

 Add ground truth data, as an alternative to comparison to production
 Make more robust, so it doesn't fail if there is user data submitted
 Test different types of queries, not just full bulk download, to cover more possible LAPIS failure modes
 Run in Github action or on cluster
 Send notifications if differences detected
title: Basic integrity checking workflow for LAPIS bulk output (metadata/sequences)

body:
This adds a test that can be run on any pathoplexus instance to determine if our LAPIS instance differs from NCBI virus - currently it only reviews that unaligned sequences are correct using the insdcAccessionBase metadata field.
It checks that the unaligned sequence in LAPIS corresponds to the unaligned sequence for the corresponding accession in NCBI virus. As insdcAccessionBase is stored with the metadata and not with unaligned sequences this should be a good way to test issues with joining them.
When tested on state-old the diff size was:

154/165 for ebola-sudan
3676/3689 for ebola-zaire
6936/6940 for west-nile
3086/3309 segments for cchf

Prod currently has no errors.

 Add some queries to the LAPIS calls and ensure integrity is maintained.
 Potentially compare all metadata fields in LAPIS - here get-released-data would be easier as ingest modifies the metadata fields a lot - however this relies on ingest more than this test.
 Check the unaligned and aligned sequences are the same
title: Compare LAPIS state to NCBI virus

body:
This test checks that insertions, unaligned and unaligned sequences have not been incorrectly stored in LAPIS.
This script gets unaligned and aligned sequences from LAPIS. For each accession we get the nucleotide insertions from LAPIS (using the nucleotideInsertions endpoint with a filter for accession). We then recreate the unaligned sequences from the aligned sequences and insertions. As insertions, unaligned and aligned sequences are all stored at a different location in LAPIS this is a good way to check for internal consistency. However, this test is very computationally intensive - so if we want to use it for production we should randonly select accessions to check.
title: Consistency testing for LAPIS storage of insertions, aligned and unaligned sequences
